questions.text: 1. A 40-year-old male who suffered myocardial infarction was given aspirin and another drug that acts by inhibiting thrombin-induced activation of platelets. The other drug given along with aspirin is _________
questions.solution:
The other drug given along with aspirin in patients with myocardial infarction is Vorapaxar. Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1(Protease Activated Receptor-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.  

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Eptifibatide is contraindicated in renal failure and tirofiban needs dose adjustment in cases of renal impairment.

questions.text: 2. The fornix ends in which structure of the floor of the third ventricle?
questions.solution:
The fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus which is marked as 'A' in the given image.

The mammillary bodies are smooth, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences, lying side by side, anterior to the posterior perforated substance, each with nuclei enclosed in fascicles of fibers derived largely from the fornix.

The fornix is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

questions.text:
3. A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
The degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of inhibitor
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S], and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax and to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence, the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition.

Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration, non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.







Pearl PM0912: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

* Competitive inhibitors

* Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: 4. A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presented with a history of mild epigastric pain and passage of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months. On further evaluation, he was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis. The TIGAR-O system used in the assessment of the underlying condition is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The TIGAR-O classification system of chronic pancreatitis is an etiological approach used to classify chronic pancreatitis. It is based on the following factors:

* Toxic-metabolic - alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia

* Idiopathic

* Genetic - PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes

* Autoimmune - autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease

* Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

* Obstructive - pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

Chronic pancreatitis is an irreversible progressive inflammatory destruction of pancreatic tissue. It results from recurrent attacks of acute pancreatitis, which clinically presents with severe abdominal pain and is later followed by exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency. 

Radiologically, there may be calcifications seen on x-ray and CT. MRI reveals multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. These strictures and stones cause alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct, leading to the chain-of-lakes appearance. ERCP and EUS can be used for imaging the accurate pancreatic anatomy.

Other features seen are:

* Visible side branching, cysts and lobularity

* Irregular main pancreatic duct

* Hyperechoic foci and strands

* Dilatation of main pancreatic duct

* Hyperechoic margins of main pancreatic duct.

Chronic pancreatitis is highly implicated if ≥4 features are present.

Most patients can be managed medically, which involves pain relief, management of diabetes, and maintenance of nutrition. Surgical interventions are done to relieve obstruction of the pancreatic duct, bile duct, or duodenum, or if there are complications.

* Hypercalcemia

* Chronic renal failure

* Medications—phenacetin abuse

* Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

* Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)

* Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)

* Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)

* Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

* Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

* IgG4 systemic

* Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

* Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)

* Recurrent acute pancreatitis

* Vascular diseases/ischemia

* Radiation-induced

Obstructive

* Pancreas divisum

* Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)

* Periampullary duodenal wall cysts

* Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

Pearl PM1641: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

* Site:

* If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;

* If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.

* Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.

* Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

* Precedes endocrine insufficiency

* Correlates with morphological changes

* Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.

* Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Pearl PM1649: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy



Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy



Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

questions.text: 5. A 35-year-old male patient presenting with abdominal pain and intractable peptic ulcers is suspected to have Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. His gastric pH is 1.5 and his fasting serum gastrin level was found to be 600pg/mL (normal 100pg/ml). What is the next best step to be done in this case?

choices.text: Level of basal acid output is measured.

questions.solution:
The given fasting serum gastrin level of 600pg/mL in a patient suspected to have Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is considered equivocal. The next best step to be done in this case is to do a secretin stimulation test. 

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

* Gastric pH should be <2 and

* Serum gastrin should be >10 times normal (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. 

Serum gastrin samples are measured before and after IV secretin administration. An increase of more than 200 pg/mL of serum gastrin above basal levels is suggestive of gastrinoma.

Conditions that can rise serum gastrin levels are:

* Use of proton pump inhibitors.

* H. pylori infection.

* Renal failure.

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Treatment of ZES

High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

* Distal Pancreatectomy – if a lesion in the body or tail of the pancreas

* Enucleation – if a lesion in the head of the pancreas

* Full-thickness excision – if lesion in duodenum

* MEN associated – surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

 For metastatic tumors:

Systemic chemotherapy  Ablations Biological therapy  Anti-VEGF

Streptozotocin

5- Fluorouracil

Doxorubicin

Radiofrequency

Cryotherapy

Interferon-alpha

Long-acting somatostatin analog

Peptide receptor radionuclides

Bevacizumab

Sunitinib


24 hr pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Pearl PM1371: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

* Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct

* Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum

* Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas



Pearl PM1372: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

* Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa

* Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach

* Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH

* Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Pearl PM1524: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

* Gastric pH <2 and

* Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

* BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)

* BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

* Initial investigation - CT or MRI

* Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound

* If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text:
7. A 65-year-old lady comes to you with a DEXA report showing T-score of -2.8 SD. Which of the following sets of serum parameters is most likely seen in this patient ?

S.No. Calcium Phosphorus Alkaline Phosphatase Parathyroid hormone
1 Decreased Decreased Increased Increased
2 Decreased Increased Increased Increased
3 Normal Normal Increased Normal
4 Normal Normal Normal Normal
questions.solution:
The DEXA report showing a T-score of -2.8 SD is suggestive of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by normal calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone levels.

T-score of -2.5 SD or lower is suggestive of osteoporosis. In this condition,the degree of mineralization remains the same. It is characterised by increased bone resorption, decreased bone formation or both. There is also a loss of structural connectivity in the trabecular bones.

Patients with osteoporosis most commonly presents with chronic back pain or pathological fractures. They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. In severe cases, the fracture of vertebrae can cause kyphosis.

DEXA scan is performed to measure bone mineral density. It helps in the diagnosis of osteoporosis and fracture risk assessment. It is used to measure the T-score.  T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

*

T-score greater than or equal to -1.0: normal bone density

*

T-score less than -1.0 to greater than -2.5: osteopenia

*

T-score less than or equal to -2.5: osteoporosis

*

T-score less than or equal to -2.5 plus fragility fracture: severe osteoporosis

Radiographic findings include loss of trabecular definition, thinning of the cortices, and fractures. In postmenopausal osteoporosis, wedging of the vertebra may be seen due to compression of vertebral bodies.

Treatment options include bisphosphonates, denosumab, parathyroid hormones (Preottact and teriparatide), selective estrogen receptor modulator, and romosozumab.

Other options 

Option A : These parameters are seen in Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D aids in the reabsorption of calcium and phosphate in the small intestine. Defects in the mucosal lining of the small intestine or inadequate exposure to sunlight can lead to Vitamin D deficiency.

Option C : An increase in ALP with normal calcium, phosphorus and parathyroid hormone is seen in Paget's disease. X - ray of the affected site would show osteolytic and sclerotic regions.

Option D : These parameters are seen in chronic kidney disease. Severe CKD can lead to hyperphosphatemia due to reduced phosphate excretion and reduced ability of the compromised kidney to activate renal vitamin D.

Pearl PM1958: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

* Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.

* Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.

* Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Pearl PM2188: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: 8. There is a small school in a village, which has students from class 1-10. The classrooms are overcrowded and the area around the school is not clean. To ensure there is no breakout of tuberculosis, which of the following methods should the school adopt as primary prevention?

choices.text: Start ATT for those that are smear positive

questions.solution:
Reducing overcrowding in classrooms is a primary prevention method. Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes/reduces the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Ex: Improving standard of living, vaccination, etc.

Other Options:

Option A: Starting ATT for those that are smear-positive would be secondary prophylaxis 

Option C: Educating children is a primordial prevention method. It aims to prevent  development of risk factors.

Option D: Screening symptomatic children with Mantoux is a secondary prevention method.

questions.text: 9. A child is being evaluated for respiratory distress. The chest radiograph of the baby is shown below. All the following are true about the condition except:

choices.text: Dextroposition can be  a clinical feature
The hernia is anterolateral in location
Scaphoid abdomen is a clinical feature
The hernia is posterolateral in location

questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph depicts Bochdalek hernia, so Option B is the correct answer here. The hernia is posterolateral in location, and not anterolateral.

Bochdalek hernia is the most common variant of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. It occurs due to defective development of the septum transversum. The defect allows the abdominal organs to enter the thoracic cavity. It is more common on the left side. The hernia is posterolateral in location. The child presents with the following clinical features:

* Respiratory distress

* Scaphoid abdomen

* Bowel sounds in the chest

* Mediastinal shift- Dextroposition of heart 

* Bilateral lung hypoplasia

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated. Bag and mask ventilation causes distension of the stomach and limits the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs leading to further respiratory distress.



Pearl PM2134: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

* The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

* The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

* respiratory distress at birth

* grunting respiration

* chest retractions

* dyspnea

* cyanosis

* scaphoid abdomen

* decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH

* shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

 



Pearl PM0028: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

* Mediastinal shift

* Bowel loops in the left hemithorax



 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

* Low lung volume

* Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)

* Air bronchogram

* White-out lung (severe disease)



Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

* Hyperinflation

* Patchy infiltrates

* Coarse streaking

questions.text: 10. A transplant recipient is kept on immunosuppressive therapy for 1 year. On follow-up visits, there is a steady rise in serum creatinine levels over a period of four months. A tissue biopsy is taken. Which of the following complement factors is a marker of humoral rejection?
questions.solution:
The complement factor which is a marker of humoral rejection is C4d

Acute antibody-mediated rejection: It is manifested mainly by damage to glomeruli and small blood vessels. There is inflammation of the glomeruli and peritubular capillaries, associated with deposition of complement products due to activation of the complement system by the antibody-dependent classical pathway

Chronic antibody-mediated rejection: It manifests as interstitial fibrosis and graft arteriosclerosis-gradual narrowing of graft blood vessels.

Immunoperoxidase stain shows C4d deposition in peritubular capillaries and a glomerulus.

Pearl PM1571: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

* Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient

* Histopathological findings:

* Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas

* Neutrophils accumulate

* Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

* Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  

* Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.

* Histopathological findings:

* Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury

* Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)

* Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 

* Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure

* Histopathological findings:

* Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.

* Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.

* Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

* Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.

* Histopathological findings:

* Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)

* Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane

* Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: 11. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of double vision and deviation of the right eye. The instrument shown below is used for examining this patient. Which of the following tests will not give additional information regarding this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a synoptophore. Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore. This patient is most likely suffering from strabismus and the Fincham test will not provide additional information in this patient.

Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes, so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion.

The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.

Binocular vision can be graded using a synoptophore.

Hirschberg Test:

It gives a rough estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is used to shine light from an arm's distance and the patient is asked to fixate. The corneal reflection of the light will be decentered in the squinting eye in the direction opposite to the deviation.

Krimsky Test:

It involves the placement of prisms in front of the fixating eye until the corneal light reflections are symmetrical. This gives an approximation of the angle of manifest deviation in strabismus. 

Maddox Wing Test:

It dissociates the eye for near fixation and measures heterophoria. 

Note: The Fincham Test is done to evaluate colored halos in cataract and distinguish it from glaucomatous degeneration.

Pearl PM2204: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo



The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

Pearl PM1016: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

* To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint

* One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.

* In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.

* When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.

* This movement is observed.

* The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.



Direct Cover test:

* Confirms the presence of manifest squint.

* Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.

* The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.

* The normal-looking eye is covered.

* In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.

* In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.



Alternate cover test:

* In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.

* Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.

* It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.

* It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: 12. A 22 year old male who is a known HIV patient presents with the complaints of anorexia, nausea and watery diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past two weeks. Given is the histology image of the patient’s jejunum. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above given image shows the histology of jejunum with basophilic spherical structures attached to microvillus surface of epithelium which is seen in Cryptosporidium hominis.

The organism is acquired by fecal–oral transmission of oocysts from either human sources (primarily) or from animal sources.

The oocysts excyst in the small intestine, where the trophozoites attach to the gut wall. Invasion does not occur. The jejunum is the site most heavily infested.  

The disease in immunocompromised patients presents primarily as a watery, nonbloody diarrhea causing large fluid loss. Symptoms persist for long periods in immunocompromised patients, whereas they are self-limited in immunocompetent patients.

Other options:

A) Isospora belli can also cause similar symptoms in immunocompromised patients, but histology shows presence of schizonts and gametocytes within the epithelial cells of the small intestine with villous atrophy and inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. (Image below)

Note : In cryptosporidiosis, it is restricted to the apical region of the epithelial cells.



C) Giardia lamblia: Organisms are teardrop (pear) shaped with paired nuclei in lumen between villi that just adheres to the duodenal epithelium or free lying in the mucosa and never invades.

D) Entamoeba histolytica most commonly affects colon rather than small intestine. Organism burrow into lamina propria and cause tissue necrosis with relatively little inflammation.

questions.text:
13. Arrange the following sentences in the correct order for activation of B cells.

1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides. 2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation. 3. Internalisation and degradation of the antigens. 4. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur. 5. Antigen binding to B cell receptor. 6. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of B cell activation is as follows:

5. Antigen binding to a B cell receptor.

3. Internalisation and degradation of the antigen.

1. T helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides.

6. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells. 

4. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur.

2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation.

On activation, B cells proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells that secrete functionally distinct classes of antibodies. Most antibody responses are T-cell-dependent. The Ig receptors on B cells recognize antigens and facilitate the endocytosis of the antigens. The endocytosed antigens are degraded and the antigen peptides are displayed bound to the MHC class-II. The T helper cells recognize these antigen peptides and express CD40 ligand.

The interaction between CD40 B cell receptors and CD40 ligand induces isotype switching. Isotype switching is the process of production of different classes of antibodies. Somatic hypermutation is the process by which antibody-producing activated B cells undergo extremely high rates of mutation in their hypervariable regions to produce antibodies specific to the antigen. The T helper cells also improve the affinity of the antibody to the antigen. This process is called affinity maturation.

questions.text: 14. A dermatology call is made for a patient with multiple soft tissue swellings over the skin and oral cavity. She was admitted for heart failure due to the presence of bilateral atrial myxomas. On examination, multiple lentigines were distributed over the body and the presence of a blue nevus on the lips was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with lentigines, atrial myxomas, mucocutaneous myxomas, and blue naevi suggests a diagnosis of LAMB syndrome. It is a part of the Carney complex.

Carney complex or myxoma syndrome is a group of disorders due to an autosomal dominant mutation in the gene encoding a subunit of protein kinase A. It presents as hyperpigmented cutaneous lesions associated with cutaneous, subcutaneous, or internal myxoma and associated endocrinopathy (of one or more of the adrenal cortex, thyroid, gonad, and pituitary gland)

Carney's complex includes: 

LAMB syndrome is lentigines (hypermelanotic patches on the skin that do not disappear on exposure to UV rays), atrial myxomas, mucocutaneous myxomas, and blue naevi.

NAME syndrome is naevi, atrial myxomas, myxoid neurofibromas, and ephelides (freckles).

Other Options:

Option A: Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disease that presents as early age photosensitivity with myriads of lentigines distributed in sun-exposed areas. The patients are at a higher risk of developing skin cancers throughout their life.

Option C: Tuberous sclerosis complex presents as cutaneous angiokeratomas, epilepsy, internal hamartomatous tumours, and learning difficulties.

Option D: Nodular basal cell carcinoma presents as surface telangiectasia over a flesh‐coloured mass or the tumour may be pink or red in colour

Pearl PM1078: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

* Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast

* Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi

* Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

* Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

* Pulmonary chondroma

* Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

* GIST

* Paraganglioma

questions.text: 15. A 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is diagnosed to have aortic dissection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Involvement of only the descending aorta requires emergency surgical repair
Can be associated with Marfan syndrome

questions.solution:
The management of aortic dissection that involves only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) is antihypertensive drugs, not emergency surgery.

Aortic dissection occurs due to the formation of a defect in the intima of the aorta, leading to the tracking of the blood through the layers of the aorta, splitting the medial layer, and thus forming a false lumen. The predisposing factors to aortic dissection include:

* Hypertension

* Marfan syndrome and other disorders of connective tissue that can cause degeneration of the tunica media of the aorta, like Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and giant cell arteritis.

* Pregnancy

The patients present with a sudden onset, tearing interscapular pain with dyspnea. General physical examination may show hypotension or hypertension and loss of pulses. Extension of the dissection in either direction can lead to symptoms related to the organ with compromised perfusion, as given below:

* Proximal extension can involve head and neck vessels (causing stroke or transient ischemic attack), coronary vessels (causing myocardial infarction) and the root of the aorta (causing aortic regurgitation).

* Distal extension can involve renal arteries (acute kidney injury), mesenteric arteries (mesenteric ischemia), spinal arteries (paraplegia) and iliac arteries (acute limb ischemia).

* The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are too unstable for transportation. In otherwise stable patients, the diagnosis is established by a CT scan. Depending on the part of the aorta involved, aortic dissections are classified as shown in the image below.



The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection (irrespective of the type) is to control hypertension and pain. A β-blocker is used parenterally, such as intravenous esmolol, to control the BP and reduce the heart rate. Sodium nitroprusside can be further added to reduce the systolic pressure to <120 mmHg.

Further management depends on the type of aortic dissection. In Stanford type A dissections, surgical intervention is required. In type B dissections, antihypertensive management is usually enough. Further intervention is indicated in type B dissections if:

* There is an increase in the pain — which could be a sign of impending rupture

* Dissection is associated with signs of reduced perfusion of organ or limb

In these complicated type B dissections, percutaneous endovascular stenting is done. Surgery is reserved for patients in whom this procedure fails.

questions.text: 16. A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, dizziness and unsteady gait. You confirm the diagnosis with the help of a brain MRI which shows a midline mass arising from the cerebellar vermis in the posterior fossa. What characteristic feature can be seen on MRI of the spine?
questions.solution:
The 5-year-old boy presenting with headache, unsteady gait and the brain MRI showing a midline mass arising from the cerebellar vermis in the posterior fossa is highly suggestive of Medulloblastoma. Spine MRI shows drop metastases which refers to the dissemination of the tumor through the CSF to anatomically lower sites like the spinal cord.

The image below is a T1-weighted MRI of the spine showing localised enhancing nodules (drop metastases) in the cervical region.



In childhood, medulloblastomas constitute the most common form of malignant neoplasm, accounting for 90% of embryonal CNS tumors. It predominantly occurs in the cerebellar vermis, which causes ataxia and unsteady gait. CT and MRI demonstrate a solid, homogeneous, contrast medium–enhancing mass in the posterior fossa causing 4th ventricular obstruction and hydrocephalus.

Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in males, presenting at a median age between 5-7 years of age, and corresponds histologically to WHO grade IV tumors. Clinical features include increased intracranial pressure manifesting as headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, and hypertension. There is also cerebellar dysfunction, which manifests as ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. 

On microscopic examination, the tumor is very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei and are characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes.



Treatment comprises a multimodal strategy that includes surgical resection with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Rugger jersey spine is seen in Hyperparathyroidism. X-ray shows alternating bands of sclerosis and lucency throughout, resembling a rugger jersey.





Option C: Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance in Ankylosing spondylitis



Option D: A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity is referred to as the Ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

questions.text: 18. A 30-year-old male patient was referred to the dermatology outpatient department with painful, erythematous nodular lesions on the extensor surface of the upper limbs. He also complains of fever and malaise. He had completed treatment for leprosy six months ago. This condition is caused by __________.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of painful, erythematous nodules over the limbs (extensor surface) in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type II lepra reaction. It is caused by type III hypersensitivity reaction which is immune-complex mediated.

Type II lepra reactions (ENL) are mainly seen in multibacillary disease; LL (50%) > BL (15%). They can occur before, during, or after treatment, and are commonly recurrent. These reactions are caused by immune complexes (type III hypersensitivity). ENL presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. Systemic manifestations like fever, malaise, anorexia, neuritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, etc. can also be seen. Treatment of type II lepra reactions includes high-dose steroids, thalidomide (drug of choice in young men with severe ENL), and clofazimine.

Type I lepra reaction, on the other hand, is caused by type IV hypersensitivity reaction, i.e. cell-mediated immune inflammation within existing skin lesions.

questions.text: 19. Mannitol use is best suited for the management of which of the following patients?

choices.text: 61-year-old patient with glioma associated cerebral edema
59-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure and a high intraocular pressure not responding to other treatment
48-year-old lady with anuria due to severe renal disease and a raised ICT
22-year-old patient with active cranial bleed and increased ICT

questions.solution:
Mannitol is indicated in patients with cerebral edema due to mass lesions

Therapeutic use of mannitol:

1. Reduction of intracranial pressure and brain mass 2. Reduction of high intraocular pressure when the pressure cannot be lowered by other means

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

Contraindications of mannitol:

* Well-established anuria due to severe renal disease

* Severe pulmonary congestion or frank pulmonary edema

* Active intracranial bleeding except during craniotomy

* Severe dehydration

* Progressive heart failure or pulmonary congestion after institution of mannitol

questions.text:
21. A 20-year-old male from West Bengal presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Sandfly was found to be the vector for his condition. Which of the following morphological form(s) is/are not seen in the causative organism ?

* Epimastigote

* Promastigote

* Trypomastigote

* Amastigote
questions.solution:
1 and 3 morphological forms are not seen(Option-C). The given clinical finding is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by Sandfly bite. Epimastigote and Trypomastigote forms are not seen in Leishmania.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

* Amastigote form: in humans and other mammals

* Promastigote form: in the sandfly and artificial culture

The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man.

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

Amastigote form: It is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is intracellular, found inside macrophages, monocytes or reticuloendothelial cells. A kinetoplast is present which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.



Promastigote form: It is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. Kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.



The lifecycle of Leishmania is shown below.



Pearl PM1757: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.



Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: 22. A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region with a history of thorn prick presents to the OPD with the following lesions. Which of the following statements is not-true regarding this condition?

choices.text: The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus.
Sclerotic bodies can be seen on microscopy
Itraconazole is the preferred drug for this condition.
The nodules appear along the lymphatics.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the distribution of the nodules along lymphatics. This distribution along the lymphatics with the history of thorn pick is suggestive of sporotrichosis, caused by the causative agent Sporothrix schenkii. Asteroid bodies are seen in sporotrichosis

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

* Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black

* Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red 

* Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) Magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.



Direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain shows the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.



Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other treatment options for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:

* Terbinafine

* SSKI- Saturated solution of potassium iodide

* Fluconazole

* Local hyperthermia

Amphotericin B can be used for disseminated infections.

Sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection. Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genus Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents. Diagnosis is made by the demonstration of sclerotic bodies (copper-penny bodies) in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae.

questions.text: 23. All of the following statements about the stab wounds are true, except ______.

choices.text: Force is along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object
Depth is greater than the length and width of the wound
Fish-tail appearance occur in single edged weapon
Swallow tails occur at angles of the main wound

questions.solution:
Swallow-tails occuring at angles of the main wound is a characteristic of laceration wound (not stab wound).

A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. (Option A)

Characteristics of stab wound:

* Margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. In full penetration of the blade, the hilt mark can be produced by the hilt guard.

* The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. 

* The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade.

* The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface (Option B). The internal depth is usually equal to or less than the length of the blade used to produce it. 

* The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc.

* In single-edged weapon- triangular/wedge-shaped with one end sharp and other 2 sides blunt. Splits may occur at the blunt end of the wound at each corner giving a fish-tail appearance. (Option C)

* In double-edged weapon- elliptical in shape with both sides sharp angles.

* Screwdriver- a slit-like stab wound 

* Fork- produces clusters of 2-3 wounds

* The wound will have a bevelled margin if the object penetrates at an angle, thus indicating the direction of penetration.

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.



Option D- Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails. It is seen in lacerated wounds.

questions.text: 24. On performing the test shown below the patient is able to breathe better. Which of the following conditions may falsely produce this result?
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is positive since the patient is able to breathe better. A false positive result is seen in the collapse of nasal ala when the ala opens up to allow better breathing and is not related to the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.



The narrowest portion of the nasal passage is known as the nasal valve area. The nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment present between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum. A positive Cottle test can be seen in deviated nasal septum (Option B), collapsed nasal valve (Option A), and valve stenosis where the nasal valve is affected. Scars/ webs in the valve (Option D) prevent the valve from opening up when the Cottle test is performed and thus, give a false negative result.

The nasal valve is the narrowest part and offers maximum resistance to airflow

LH- Luteinizing hormone

questions.solution:
The second statement i.e. that secondary oocytes arrest in metaphase of the first meiotic division is not true.

The secondary oocyte actually arrests in the metaphase of the second meiotic division. (Option C)

27. A postgraduate student, while assisting an emergency trauma surgery on an HIV-infected patient, has suffered a bleeding puncture wound in his right index finger. The post-exposure prophylaxis is given for 4 weeks. Which of these represent the correct daily dosage of the given drugs?

A. Lamivudine B. Tenofovir C. Dolutegravir

1. 50 mg 2. 100 mg 3. 300 mg
questions.solution:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes lamivudine 300mg , tenofovir 300mg and dolutegravir 50mg. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.

Most common cause of HIV in a healthcare worker is due to needle stick injuries. Exposure to needle stick injuries can be prevented by:

* Using barriers (goggles, gloves,) during performing procedures that cause exposure to blood/ body fluids

* Hand washing and routine disinfection of surfaces.

* Careful handling and disposing of sharps and needles after use.

The protocol followed after exposure is: Exposure within the past 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 4 weeks prescription with drug information --> routine HIV antibody testing upto 6 months after exposure.

questions.text:
28. A 12-year-old boy was brought with progressive right hip pain for 1 month. He had many episodes of pain and swelling of his hands. His brother had a stroke at age 6. Physical examination shows tenderness over the right hip with no gross skin changes. His blood smear shows the findings in the picture. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hip pain?

Vitals and Labs:

BP: 116/76 mm of Hg

Pulse: 80 bpm

Temp: 99 F

TLC: 5,000 /mm3
questions.solution:
The findings of dactylitis and family history of stroke at a young age, along with sickle cells in the blood smear, are suggestive of sickle cell disease (SCD).

This patient's hip pain in the absence of fever and normal leukocyte count is due to infarction or avascular necrosis (AVN) of the hip joint due to vaso-occlusion by sickle cells. The AVN of the hip may cause limp and leg-length discrepancies. 

Manifestations of sickle cell disease include:

* Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, necessitating emergency transfusion/splenectomy

* Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue

* Renal papillary necrosis

* Cerebrovascular strokes

* Chronic lower leg ulcers

* Priapism in males

The cardinal clinical feature of sickle cell anemia is acute vaso-occlusive pain, due to ischemia of the tissues. Vasoocclusive crisis can cause dactylitis, splenic infarction (shrunken spleen over time), AVN, etc. Most commonly, the femoral head is affected in AVN. Other sites affected include the humeral head and mandible.

Dactylitis referred to as a hand-foot syndrome, is often the first manifestation of pain in infants and young children with sickle cell anemia. Dactylitis often manifests with symmetric or unilateral swelling of the hands and/or feet.  

Other Options:

Option B- Septic arthritis manifests as fever, unilateral joint pain, and restricted motion. Although SCD patients have a higher risk of septic arthritis but no evidence of fever, joint swelling, and normal leukocyte count, rules out this diagnosis.

Option C- Patients with osteomyelitis often have a longer duration of fever and pain, swelling of the affected area, fewer or only 1 location of pain and tenderness, higher white blood cell counts, and an elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures, when positive, are helpful. Both Salmonella spp. and S. aureus causes osteomyelitis in children with sickle cell anemia, which is often in the diaphysis of long bones.

Option D-  Pseudogout or gout occurs due to crystal deposition in the joint. It also presents with unilateral joint pain. But there is also the presence of skin erythema and joint swelling with usually an acute onset. This patient has had pain in the joint for 1 month.

questions.text: 29. A 3-day-old male newborn is admitted to the hospital because of lethargy and poor feeding. His condition progressively deteriorates and he is now in a coma. Serum ammonia levels are found to be elevated and urine shows the presence of orotic acid. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male newborn presenting with features of hyperammonemia (lethargy, poor feeding, seizures) along with elevated serum ammonia levels and orotic aciduria is suggestive of ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency. 

OTC catalyzes the conversion of carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to citrulline. OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Clinical manifestations vary in severity from lethargy to encephalopathy and coma. Confirmatory tests for OTC deficiency include analyzing the plasma amino acid profile, which will show a low citrulline level, and increased glutamate and alanine. Urine shows the presence of orotic acid.

Other options:

Option A: Orotic aciduria occurs due to a defect in the enzyme UMP synthase (de-novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway). This leads to elevation of orotic acid in the blood and the urine. The clinical manifestations include failure to thrive, developmental delay, and megaloblastic anaemia refractory to folate and vitamin B12 supplementation. There is no hyperammonemia, which is seen in OTC deficiency. The treatment consists of administrating uridine to bypass the deficient enzyme. 

Option B: Propionic acidemia presents with hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. There will be no orotic acid in the urine. 

Option D: Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency presents with hyperammonemia and hypoketotic hypoglycemia. There will be no orotic acid in the urine.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 30. Which among the following layer has abundant desmosomes ?
questions.solution:
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes.

The image shows layers of the epidermis, which is divided from deep to superficial as 

* Stratum basale (Basal layer)

* Stratum spinosum (Spinous or prickle cell layer)

* Stratum granulosum (Granular layer)

* Stratum lucidum (Clear layer)

* Stratum corneum (Cornified layer)

Stratum spinosum contains several layers of closely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with each other by means of numerous cell surface projections. These cells are anchored to each other by desmosomes that provide tensile strength and cohesion to the layer. When the skin is seen under light microscopy, the cells tend to shrink away except where they are joined by desmosomes, giving them a spiny appearance. 

Desmosomes are the major intercellular junctions in the skin that join the adjacent keratinocytes. They contain 3 proteins inside: Desmoglein (dsg), Desmocollin, and Desmoplakin.

questions.text: 31. A patient underwent surgery for varicose veins. The saphenous nerve is suspected to have been injured during the stripping of the great saphenous vein. The patient may develop loss of sensation in which of the following area?
questions.solution:
The patient may develop a loss of sensation in the medial part of the foot, marked as area 3 in the image, as it is supplied by the saphenous nerve.



Innervation of the dorsum of the foot is provided medially by the saphenous nerve, laterally by the sural nerve, and centrally by the superficial peroneal nerve. The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

The saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. 

The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. During the stripping of veins for varicose vein management, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein.

questions.text: 33. A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding the tests used for detecting the causative organisms?

choices.text: Shows stormy fermentation on litmus milk test
Shows target hemolysis on blood agar
Elek’s gel precipitation test is positive

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Elek’s gel precipitation test is an immunodiffusion test used to check the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores (sporulates only outside the human body). Naegler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium.

It is an anaerobe and grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis (Option B). A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to θ-toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to α-toxin results in the development of target hemolysis on blood agar by C. perfringens.

In the reverse CAMP test (Option C), C.perfringens is streaked over the center of the plate and Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. α-toxin produced by C.perfringens interacts with the CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis.



In the litmus milk test fermentation of lactose by Clostridium leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.



Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: 34. A 16-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatric emergency department after she slashed her wrist in an attempt to commit suicide. Her father reveals that there were multiple such attempts in the past. She has a history of marked fluctuations of mood and unstable relationships in the past. Which of the following non-pharmacological therapy is advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy advised for this patient is dialectical behavioral therapy.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP), and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various psychotherapies used in the treatment of this condition. There is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

* Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment

* Unstable interpersonal relationships

* Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self

* Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.

* Repeated suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior

* Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood

* Prolonged feeling of emptiness

* Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger

* Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. 

Antipsychotics help to control anger, hostility, and brief psychotic episodes. Antidepressants are used to improve depressive mood which is common in patients with borderline personality disorder.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors help in the modulation of impulsive behavior and benzodiazepine-like alprazolam helps in improving anxiety and depression. Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine help in improving the global functioning of patients with borderline personality disorder. 

Other options:

Interpersonal psychotherapy is used in the treatment of depression. It focuses on grief over loss, interpersonal disputes, interpersonal skill deficits, and role transitions.

Exposure and response prevention is used in the treatment of OCD.

35. A 25-year-old male patient presented with a painless, hard testicular lump with a dragging sensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is least likely to be included in further management of this case?

AFP- Alpha Fetoprotein

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of painless testicular swelling with raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the testis. Orchidectomy via inguinal approach is done in this case rather than a scrotal approach due to fear of seeding the tumor in the scrotal skin. Hence, it is least likely to be the management of this case.

Management of testicular tumors:

* Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor.

* Tumor markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer.

* CT - chest, abdomen, and pelvis is done to detect metastasis.

* Orchidectomy via an inguinal incision (high inguinal orchidectomy) is the best line of treatment in case of suspected testicular tumor.

* Further management is based on staging. The older staging is preferred over the TNM staging for treatment and is given below:

* Stage I: Tumour is confined to testis and epididymis

* Stage II: Nodal tissue is present but is confined to nodes below the diaphragm

* Stage III: Nodal involvement above the diaphragm

* Stage IV: Non-lymphatic metastatic spread (mostly in lungs)

* Stage I tumors:

* Combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy) is given for NSGCTs, as they are radio-resistant.

* Chemotherapy with cisplatinum and radiotherapy to para-aortic lymph nodes can be given in seminomas as they are radiosensitive.

* Stage II-IV tumors (seminomas and NSGCTs) are treated with BEP chemotherapy and retroperitoneal lymph node dissection if needed.

Note:

In case of suspected testicular tumors,

* No scrotal approach.

* No FNAC.

* No incisional biopsy.

questions.text: 39. A 24-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with a history of fall on a flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the forearm. On examination, there is tenderness and painful dorsiflexion of the wrist. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements are false about this condition?

choices.text: Unstable fractures are fixed with percutaneous pins or small screws
Stable fractures are managed with short arm cast
They are best seen on lateral view

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the X-ray showing the dorsal segment of distal radius fracture extending into the intra-articular region is suggestive of dorsal Barton's fracture. Barton's fractures are invariably intra-articular fractures. 

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. The dorsal or volar rim of the distal radius can be involved and they are named accordingly.

Dorsal Barton:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the distal radius. It is caused due to falling on the flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the distal forearm. These fractures are best seen on the lateral view and the radiograph shows proximal and posterior displacement of the dorsal lip of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management is by short arm cast with the wrist in the neutral position. Surgical management is by open reduction and internal fixation with percutaneous pins or small plates and screws.

Volar Barton/Palmar rim dislocation:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the anterior/palmar rim of the distal radius. It is caused by palmar tensile stress and dorsal shear stress and may be associated with radial styloid fractures. The radiograph shows dorsal displacement of the palmar rim of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management - long-arm cast. Even though reduction is simple, retention is usually difficult. Surgical fixation with K- wires, external fixators, and buttress plates are considered if the reduction is not properly retained. Ellis-T-shaped buttress plate fixation is mostly preferred.

questions.text: 40. A 24-year-old man presents with lower back pain. He is evaluated and diagnosed to have ankylosing spondylitis. Which among the following is the earliest vertebral change seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The earliest vertebral change in ankylosing spondylitis is the squaring of the vertebra or flattening of the anterior concavity of the vertebral bodies.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that mainly affects the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is commonly seen in young male adults and has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker

ASAS categorisation criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients <45 years with lower back pain of 3 months duration. The criteria comprise 2 sections, one radiological section and one clinical section:

* To qualify for the radiological section - sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI + at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis 

* To qualify for the clinical section - a positive HLA B27 + at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis 

Features of spondyloarthritis: 

* Low inflammatory pain

* Arthritis

* Enthesitis

* Uveítis

* Dactylitis

* Psoriasis

* Crohn/colitis

* Good response to NSAID

* Family history of spondyloarthropathy

* HLA B27

* High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

* Sacro-iliac joints - 

* Cardinal sign/earliest sign - erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints

* Later - peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint

* Vertebral changes - 

* Earliest - flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)

* Later - ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae

* Bamboo spine appearance - due to bridging at several vertebral levels

* Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.

* Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

The most common serious complication of ankylosing spondylitis is a spinal fracture. The lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture. The other complications include gluteal muscle atrophy, loss of lumbar curvature, kyphosis, etc.

questions.text: 41. In a patient with pneumonia, which of the following auscultatory findings is most likely to be heard over the affected lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
In a patient with pneumonia, bronchial breath sounds are most likely to be heard over the affected lobe of the lung. This is because the affected lobe is airless due to consolidation, which transmits the sounds of large airways more effectively.

Normal breath sounds are termed as vesicular breath sounds. They are of rustling or breezy quality. Normal lung tissue makes the breath sounds quieter by selectively filtering out the higher frequencies. The duration of the inspiratory phase is longer than the expiratory phase. There is no pause between inspiration and expiration.

Bronchial breath sounds are rather harsh in quality. They are normally heard anteriorly over the manubrium and posteriorly between the C7 and T3 vertebrae. Bronchial breath sounds contain higher frequency components because the filtering function of the normal lung parenchyma is lost, as occurs in consolidation. The expiratory phase is longer than the inspiratory phase. There is a distinct pause between inspiration and expiration due to the absent alveolar phase.

questions.text: 42. A 7-year-old girl presents with short stature and bilateral genu valgus. Laboratory investigations show reduced serum phosphate and phosphaturia. The detailed pedigree of her family is given below. Which of the following is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree is suggestive of an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. The disorder in question is likely to be X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets.

Points in favor of an X -linked dominant inheritance in the given pedigree include:

* Females are affected more than males.

* Affected female transmits the disease to half her sons and daughters.

* Affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.

The following flowchart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.



X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH) occurs because of a defect in the PHEX gene. Since the PHEX gene is responsible for inactivating FGF-23, there is an increased FGF-23 in XLH. Increased FGF-23 inhibits phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule of the kidney and causes phosphaturia. It also inhibits 1-α-hydroxylase, leading to decreased production of activated vitamin D.

Patients with XLH present with clinical features suggestive of rickets such as short stature and genu valgus, genu varum or windswept deformity. The patients have high renal excretion of phosphate, hypophosphatemia, and increased ALP. The treatment in these patients consists of oral phosphorous and calcitriol administration.
