questions.text:
79. An elderly man presents with sudden onset chest pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. His heart rate is 122/min, jugular venous pressure is elevated, and lung fields are clear. He underwent surgery three weeks ago and is on complete rest. He was treated for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago. His ECG shows S1Q3T3 changes. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the diagnosis.

* Pericardial friction rub present on auscultation.

* Modified Well's score is 8.5 in this patient.

* Chest CT is the principal imaging test for diagnosis.

* Pulmonary angiography is the principal imaging test for diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The statements 2 and 3 are correct.

This patient is most likely suffering from acute pulmonary embolism (PE) as evidenced by his clinical symptoms of acute cor pulmonale (right heart dysfunction), ECG showing S1Q3T3 changes, and modified Well's score of >4.

This patient has a modified Well's score of 8.5 (Pulmonary embolism is likely, if the score is more than 4):

* Heart rate >100 beats/min- score 1.5

* Hemoptysis- score 1

* Recent history of immobilization due to surgery- score 1.5

* Past history of deep vein thrombosis- score 1.5

* Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely- score 3

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, representative of a prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow), Q wave in lead III (red arrow), and an inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow)



CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. It can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Lung scanning is the second-line diagnostic test for PE, used in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

MR pulmonary angiography is a reliable test to identify deep vein thrombosis. It may detect large proximal PE, but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Pulmonary angiography- Because of the invasive nature of the test and availability of the chest CT scans, it is not commonly used in the diagnosis of PE. It is reserved for patients with technically unsatisfactory chest CTs.

Echocardiography- Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram, therefore, it is not a reliable test. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.



Differentials: 

Pleural effusion is a collection of fluid within the pleural space because of various etiologies (infectious, malignant, cardiopulmonary). It is characterized by pleuritic chest pain, progressive dyspnea, and cough. Respiratory system examination reveals:

* stony dullness on percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and diminished breath sounds on the side of the effusion

* pleural friction rub may be heard on auscultation

* ECG: normal or non-specific findings such as low voltage QRS, axis deviation, and/or electrical alternans

Acute pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac and is characterized by pleuritic chest pain as seen in this patient with PE. However, examination findings reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

questions.text:
80. Arrange the following events of embryonal development during the second to the fourth week in the sequence in which they occur:

* Formation of the neural plate

* Formation of the notochordal process

* Formation of the primitive streak 

* Notochordal plate separates from endoderm to form true notochord

* Formation of the notochordal plate
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in which the above events occur is 3, 2, 1, 5, 4: Formation of the primitive streak, notochordal process, neural plate, notochordal plate, and finally, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form the true notochord.

The primitive streak is formed around day 15. This is followed by the formation of definitive endoderm and the formation of mesoderm.

This mesoderm extends cranially to form the notochordal process around day 17. Meanwhile, the mesoderm present lateral to midline gets divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral plate mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm splits into two layers- somatic mesoderm and splanchnic mesoderm, separated by the intraembryonic coelom.

Formation of the neural plate begins between days 19 and 20. The cranial and caudal parts of the neural plate represent the future brain and spinal cord, respectively.

The notochordal process fuses transiently with the endoderm to form a notochordal plate after day 20. Finally, around day 22, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form a solid, definitive notochord.

questions.text: 81. A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Which among the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the management for this patient would be wide excision.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Other options:

Option A: Curettage is mainly used for the management of giant cell tumors. It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor presenting in the 2nd-4th decade with distal femoral metaphysis or epiphysis as the most common site. Radiographic findings include solitary lytic lesion and soap bubble appearance and the below image shows the same



Option B: Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for osteoid osteoma. It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur.

Option D: Intralesional steroids are used in the management of simple bone cysts that occur most commonly in males near the metaphyseal areas. On X-rays, it shows a fallen leaf sign ( a small fragment is seen within the cavity)

questions.text: 82. A 7-year-old boy presents with a visual acuity of 6/6 in the right eye and only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. Left eye fundoscopic appearance is as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy in his first decade of life with a unilateral decrease in visual acuity with fundus showing telangiectasia and severe lipid deposition points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats' disease is a congenital vascular disorder of the eye typically seen in boys in their first decade and is usually unilateral. In children, Coats’ disease is typically diagnosed as a result of recognition of poor vision, strabismus, or leukokoria.

Early stages of ocular manifestations include discrete zones with dilated and tortuous retinal blood vessels and a number of small aneurysms near the posterior pole and around the disc. The ophthalmoscopic picture shows retinal vascular abnormalities associated with large areas of intra and subretinal yellowish exudates and hemorrhages.

Given below is the fundus picture of Coats’ disease showing aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe macular lipid deposition.



Other options:

Option A- Central serous retinopathy is characterized by spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. The fundus findings include mild elevation of the macular area, absent or distorted foveal reflex, and subretinal deposits. The given below is the fundus picture of central serous retinopathy.



Option B- Purtscher retinopathy is characterized by multiple retinal white areas around the optic nerve head and fovea (Purtscher flecken), cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhages. The given below is the fundus picture of Purtscher retinopathy.



Option D- Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text: 83. A patient undergoing surgery suddenly developed a temperature of 102 F and a pulse rate of 130 bpm. His capnograph shows the following finding. Your senior resident injects intravenous dantrolene immediately. All the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia managed with intravenous dantrolene. All the above-mentioned drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except calcium channel blockers as they may cause hyperkalemia when used in combination with dantrolene.

The capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in EtCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Dantrolene sodium is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg) till the attack subsides.

Correction of Electrolyte Imbalances:

* Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.

* Hyperkalemia should be treated with insulin.

* Furosemide may be used to induce diuresis and prevent acute kidney failure.

Other treatment options:

* All anesthetic agents should be cut off.

* Hyperventilation with 100% O2.

* If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs, and cooling blankets.

Pearl PM0186: Various capnography waveforms:



A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning C- Inspiratory valve malfunction D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA E- Curare cleft F- Rebreathing G- Esophageal intubation H- Spontaneous breathing I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor J- Malignant hyperthermia K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor. The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.  M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient. N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.  O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Pearl PM0183: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

* Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

* Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane

* Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

* Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis

* Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia

* Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria

* Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

* Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents

* Hyperventilation with 100% O2

* Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).

* Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 

* Cooling the patient

Solid and short fangs, incomplete belly scales that do not cover the entire breadth, and bite wound showing a number of small teeth marks in a row are usually seen with non-venomous snakes.

A conspicuous pit between the eye and nostril is mostly seen in pit vipers, which are venomous. Other features of venomous snakes include small head scales, large belly scales that cover the entire belly, and long and canalized fangs.

questions.text: 85. Which of the following is false regarding the procedure performed with the following set of instruments?

choices.text: Best placement of the tube for suctioning is postpyloric
It is contraindicated in significant facial trauma
Length is measured from tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm position

questions.solution:
The given instrument tray shows instruments required for insertion of a nasogastric tube which is placed before the pylorus when used for suction to avoid damage to the duodenum.

Nasogastric tubes play a standard role in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.

NEX method:

* Nose–Ear–Xiphisternum 

* The tube length should be estimated before insertion.

* Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Approximate length to be inserted: 55cms

Ideally, Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

* Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air

* An abdominal x-ray is the best way to confirm the location of the tube

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

Indications for NG tube :

* Aspiration of gastric fluid

* Gastric decompression

* Feeding

* Administration of medication

* Bowel irrigation

Contraindications:

Absolute:

* Severe midface trauma

questions.text: 86. A 3-day-old neonate is being evaluated for the findings shown below. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Neonatal seizures are defined as the occurrence of sudden, paroxysmal, abnormal alteration of electrographic activity at any point from birth to the end of the neonatal period. It can be focal clonic, focal tonic, myoclonic seizure, or epileptic spasm. 

 A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

* Maybe unifocal or multifocal.

* May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body

* May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides.

* It cannot be suppressed by restraint.

* Focal clonic seizures can be unifocal or restricted to specific muscles, including proximal or distal limbs, trunk or neck, or regions of face

* These seizures may migrate from one region to another according to traditional Jacksonian features

Video-EEG is the gold standard for diagnosis and quantification of seizures in neonates, with clinical observation and EEG monitoring

MRI (option C) is preferred to evaluate for hypoxic-ischemic injury, intracranial hemorrhage, ischemic stroke, or brain malformations

Genetic testing for evidence of KCNQ2 (Option D) mutations is positive in a large majority of patients. It also helps in specific treatments for some associated syndromes. 

CT (Option A) is avoided in neonates since MRI provides better resolution without exposure to ionizing radiation.

WHO recommendation:

* Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.

* If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.

* In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: 87. A young man was started on the drug which is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of platelet after percutaneous coronary intervention. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention, as it decreases thrombotic cardiovascular events. 

Side effects include bleeding and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura in rare cases. Administration of prasugrel with an anticoagulant or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug is avoided as it may increase the risk of bleeding. Contraindicated in patients above 75 years of age and those with a history of cerebrovascular disease.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Tirofiban acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. It has a short duration of action and is used for the management of patients with non–ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome.

Option C: Eptifibatide acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: 88. A 35-year-old man, with a known doxycycline allergy, presented with painful swellings on both sides of the groin, as shown in the image. Which of the following is suitable to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of painful swellings and the image of enlarged lymph nodes in both groins indicate inguinal adenitis, or buboes, in this patient. These findings are suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The first-line therapy for LGV is doxycycline for 21 days. But, since this patient is allergic to doxycycline, erythromycin for 21 days, which is considered the second-line agent, can be used as an alternative.   

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.

It occurs in three stages:

* The primary stage lasts for about 3–30 days after infection, and the lesion is a single, non-indurated, shallow ulcer or pustule or papule that may be painless. It heals rapidly, without any scar formation.

* The secondary stage occurs about 2-6 weeks after the primary stage and manifests as painful lymphadenopathy that may be unilateral or bilateral and enlarged, tender, painful glands in the groin called buboes. A groove-like depression may be observed above and below the inguinal ligament due to enlargement of femoral or inguinal lymph nodes; this is called the groove sign.

* The tertiary stage follows chronic untreated infection. It is associated with stricture formation and fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region. Chronic disfiguring granulomatous fibrosis and scarring of the vulva with esthiomene formation are also observed in this stage.

The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of LGV.

questions.text: 89. A 35-year-old P2L2 lady with uterine fibroid did not show a response to hormonal therapy for 8 months. She asks for information on other treatment options, one of which is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the procedure shown?

choices.text: Synthetic particulate emboli delivered into both uterine arteries.
There is no risk of complications with future pregnancies post this procedure.
Endometrial malignancy is the absolute contraindication.
Permanent amenorrhea can develop in older reproductive-age patients.

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is uterine artery embolization (UAE), and option B is the incorrect statement.

UAE is an angiographic procedure where synthetic particulate emboli are injected into both uterine arteries. This hampers the uterine blood flow through the larger vessels supplying leiomyomas, producing ischemia and necrosis of fibroids, while sparing the surrounding myometrium. 

Uterine artery embolization can be done prior to definitive surgery, in order to reduce vascularity and fibroid size. It is a management option for women who would undergo a hysterectomy or myomectomy and have no desire for future pregnancy.

Post-embolization pregnancy is associated with the risk of uterine rupture, postpartum hemorrhage, miscarriage, and cesarean delivery. Occasionally, some patients, often older reproductive-age patients, may develop permanent amenorrhea. This is seen due to the concurrent embolization of the ovaries.

Absolute contraindication includes pregnancy, active uterine or adnexal infection, and suspected reproductive tract malignancy.



Pearl PM1002: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

* GnRH agonist use

* Asymptomatic fibroids

* Pregnancy

* Pelvic inflammatory disease

* Uterine malignancy

* Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

* Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 

* Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.

* Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.

* Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 

* Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: 90. A 65-year-old male patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) of the left kidney is admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management. A contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows the presence of growth in the left kidney. Which is the surest finding that you will use to label the tumor as stage 4 RCC?

choices.text: Involvement of wall of vena cava

questions.solution:
Extent beyond Gerota's fascia is the surest finding to label the tumor as stage 4 RCC.

The staging of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is based on size, position, and lymph node involvement. The stages and the features of each stage are given below.

Stage of RCC Features 
Stage I Tumor <7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage II Tumor >7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage III Tumor in the major veins, or invading the wall of vena cava with intact Gerota’s fascia, or regional lymph nodes involved
Stage IV Tumor beyond Gerota's fascia


Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises from the epithelium of the proximal convoluted tubule and is frequently detected coincidentally. It has a male preponderance.

There are six major subtypes which are clear-cell, papillary, chromophobe, MiT family translocation, collecting duct, and medullary type.

The classic triad of loin pain, loin mass, and haematuria is seen in <10% of patients with renal tumors. Rather, the majority of diagnoses result from incidental findings during procedures like CT imaging, performed for other reasons.

Major risk factors for RCC include age, sex, obesity, hypertension, and cigarette smoking. Other medical conditions associated with RCC include chronic kidney disease, hemodialysis, kidney transplantation, and acquired cystic disease of the kidney (ACDK).

Genetic factors also contribute to an increased risk of RCC, evidenced by individuals with a family history of renal cancer having an approximately two-fold increased risk. The most common symptoms associated with paraneoplastic syndromes are hypercalcemia, fever, and erythrocytosis.

Surgeries done for RCC:

* Partial nephrectomy, the goal of which is to completely remove the primary tumor while preserving the largest possible amount of healthy renal parenchyma. It is done for all T1a tumors (<4 cm) and most T1b tumours (well-selected 4-7 cm tumors)

* Classic radical nephrectomy involves the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.

There also exist targeted therapies for RCC, which include tyrosine kinase inhibitors like sorafenib, sunitinib, and lenvatinib; anti-VEGF monoclonal antibodies like bevacizumab; and mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and temsirolimus. The average duration of disease control with these agents is 8–9 months.

questions.text:
91. A pregnant lady has undergone a glucose tolerance test according to IADPSG guidelines. The blood glucose levels were found to be 90mg/dL, 173mg/dL, and 135mg/dL at fasting, 1-hr and 2-hr of glucose administration respectively. What is the most appropriate next step in this case?

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel

choices.text: Advise her only regular exercises as the values are normal
Start her on a diabetic diet

questions.solution:
The test performed here is a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) according to the IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups Consensus Panel) guidelines. It is a single-step diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. Blood glucose levels are checked at fasting, and after the first and second hour of administering the glucose. As none of the values meets the IADPSG criteria, this patient is normal and needs no further evaluation. Hence, she is advised to continue her regular exercises.

Gestational diabetes is defined as carbohydrate intolerance of varying severity that is diagnosed in pregnancy. It presents in the second, or most commonly in the third trimester. It is not seen in the first trimester. It usually resolves within 6 weeks of delivery.

It occurs due to the combined effect of HPL (human placental lactogen), estrogen, progesterone, free cortisol and also due to the degradation of the insulin by the placenta. All these hormonal changes lead to an increase in insulin demand as the pregnancy advances. The insulin resistance is found to be the maximum at 24 to 28 weeks of gestation, hence this condition is never seen in the first trimester.

OGTT (oral glucose tolerance test) is done twice during the antenatal period.

* In the first trimester - to detect overt diabetes

* Then between 24-28 weeks period of gestation (POG) - to detect gestational diabetes.

DIPSI- Diabetes In Pregnancy Study Group India ACOG- American College of Obstetrics & Gynaecology OGCT- Oral glucose challenge test

Once diagnosed with gestational diabetes, a diabetic diet is advised for 2 weeks. At the end of 2 weeks, a 2-hr OGTT is done. If the blood glucose level is <120 mg/dL, the diabetic diet is continued. If ≥ 120 mg/dL, insulin is started. Regular insulin and NPH is preferred. But if the patient refuses to take insulin, only then oral hypoglycaemic agents (OHAs) like metformin or glyburide can be used.

questions.text: 94. A population of 1000 children under 10 years living in town X is studied. 200 children have been diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and are treated. 5 years later, 180 children are alive and doing well. What is the survival rate?
questions.solution:
Survival rate in this case is 90%. Survival rate is defined as the proportion of survivors in a group, (e.g. of patients) studied and followed over a period (e.g. a 5-year period).

The formula of survival rate is given as follows: Total number of patients alive after 5 years/Total number of patients diagnosed or treated x 100

Here, 180 patients were alive at the end of 5 years, making the survival rate: 180/200 x 100 = 90%.

The survival rate is a method of describing prognosis in certain disease conditions. It can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy. Survival rates have received special attention in cancer studies.

questions.text: 95. A 51-year-old female patient, Mrs. Susheela presents to dermatology OPD with a rash as seen in the image below. On further inquiry, she reveals that she has unintentionally lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Medical history is significant for a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she is being treated with T. Metformin 500mg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts necrolytic migrating erythema. This along with the clinical presentation is strongly suggestive of a glucagonoma. 

Glucagonoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, a majority of which are malignant at the time of presentation. They are most commonly seen arising from the pancreatic tail.

Clinically, the classic presentation of glucagonoma is with the “4 D’s”-

* Diabetes

* Dermatitis- A characteristic waxing and waning necrolytic migrating erythema is seen that usually appears before other symptoms.

* Deep vein thrombosis 

* Depression.

Diagnosis is established by estimating plasma glucagon levels. A level >1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic (normal plasma glucagon level is <150 pg/mL). Hypoaminoacidemia is also a characteristic laboratory finding. 

Treatment may include long-acting somatostatin analogues like octreotide to alleviate some of the clinical symptoms such as dermatitis. Surgical resection may be attempted but is often unsuccessful due to extrapancreatic malignant spread at the time of diagnosis.

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: 96. A 45-year-old man has chronic hypertension since 10 years. He has tried three different drugs A, B, and C to control his hypertension over the years. The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

* It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.

* It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.

* In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.



Potency:

* It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 

* A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.

* The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)

questions.text: 97. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in α-galactosidase A enzyme. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism due to deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes.

Features of Fabry disease:

* Angiokeratomas - telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area

* Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating

* Corneal and lenticular opacities

* Painful acroparesthesias 

* Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities

* Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent Maltese cross

Arrhythmias, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure are some of the important cardiovascular manifestations. The most common valvular lesion is mitral insufficiency. Cardiac arrhythmias may result in transient ischemic attacks and stroke. Renal failure, characterized by proteinuria, isosthenuria, azotemia, and gradual deterioration of renal function, is seen. Renal failure, cardiac disease, or stroke are the major causes of mortality in patients with Fabry disease.

Below is the image of angiokeratomas distributed along the bathing trunk area.



Other options:

Option A- Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option B- Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides, preferentially in the central nervous system. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. 

Option D- Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the reticuloendothelial system. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

99. An ophthalmic surgeon while performing surgery removes all the contents of an eyeball and leaves only a 3 mm frill of the sclera around the optic nerve. Which of the following is an indication for this procedure?

* Retinoblastoma

* Bleeding anterior staphyloma

* Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage

* Malignant melanoma

* Unresponsive orbital mucormycosis
questions.solution:
The surgery, which is being performed here is a frill evisceration operation which is indicated in bleeding anterior staphyloma and expulsive choroidal hemorrhage.

Evisceration operation:

It is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration. In this, only about 3mm frill of the sclera is left around the optic nerve.

Indications of evisceration

* Panophthalmitis

* Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage

* Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Enucleation operation: It is the complete excision of an eyeball.

Absolute indications are:

* Retinoblastoma (Option 1)

* Malignant melanoma (Option 4)

Note: Indication for eye donation: Removal of eyes from the cadaver is presently the most common indication for enucleation.

Exenteration is a mutilating surgery in which all contents of the orbits along with periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball. Orbital mucormycosis (Option 5) is a rare indication of exenteration, particularly in unresponsive cases.

questions.text: 100. In an experiment, a researcher is using gene knockout technology and inducing cell death. The following pattern is visualized in an agarose gel by ethidium bromide staining of DNA fragments released from these cells. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this mechanism of cell death?

choices.text: BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 promote cell death
Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in the process
Annexin V is a marker for this process
Caspase-8 plays an important role in the intrinsic pathway

questions.solution:
Annexin V is a marker for this process.

 

The given image shows the characteristic DNA ladder pattern visualized in the agarose gel electrophoresis with an ethidium bromide stain which is indicative of apoptosis.

Apoptosis is defined as the programmed cell death characterized by activation of intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' genomic DNA, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:

* BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic genes that keep the outer mitochondrial membrane-impermeable to death-inducing proteins. Thereby they prevent the leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.

* BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic factors that insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.

* Initiators of apoptosis include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. Their activity is upregulated and activated by sensors of cellular stress and damage.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

Cell injury results in the release of cytochrome c and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria. Cytochrome c binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming apoptosome. These then activate caspase 9 which cause nuclear fragmentation and the formation of apoptotic bodies

Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

In this pathway, activation of death receptors causes apoptosis by activating caspase-8. Prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95). Fas ligand (FasL) binds to Fas and forms a binding site to the FADD (Fas-associated death domain). This activates caspase 8 and initiates apoptosis.

Other Options:

Option A- BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic molecules.

Option B- Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in necrosis.

Option D- Caspase-8 plays an important role in the extrinsic pathway.

questions.text: 101. An elderly woman presents to you with multiple joint pains. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the ring and little finger. This deformity is called:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The is showing hyperextension of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and flexion at proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints suggestive of Boutonniere deformity.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness lasting >1 hour that relieves with activity.

A Boutonniere deformity occurs due to the rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon. Normally, the central slip of the extensor tendon inserts into the base of the middle phalanx. Following rupture of the central slip, the lateral slips also separate creating a gap. The head of the proximal phalanx goes through the gap, resembling a button going through a buttonhole.

The image below shows the two most common deformities in RA.



Being a systemic disease, RA causes various extra-articular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and anemia of chronic disease.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), and CRP (C reactive protein). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), glucocorticoids, and DMARDs (disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs) like methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, leflunomide. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, abatacept, anakinra, rituximab, and interleukin -6 inhibitors are also helpful in RA.

questions.text: 102. A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggests that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Zeimann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae has the lowest degree of parasitization. 

P.vivax has ring forms that resemble P.malariae but they are thinner and less intensely stained. Erythrocytes are enlarged, and pale with Schuffner's dots. 

In P.ovale, the infected erythrocytes are slightly enlarged and oval shape with fimbriated margins. Prominent Schuffner's dots are present on the erythropcyte. 

Erythrocyte in P.falciparum initially will show marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shoes a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

103. A researcher conducting multiple genetic studies observes that targeted mutations within certain genes can induce defects in DNA repair and dramatically increase susceptibility to cancer. Which of the following diseases is incorrectly matched with the DNA repair mechanisms?

SCID- Severe combined immunodeficiency.

choices.text: Xeroderma pigmentosum - Defective nucleotide excision repair
Lynch syndrome - Defective base excision repair

questions.solution:
Lynch syndrome, or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), occurs due to a defective DNA mismatch repair mechanism. Defective DNA base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost, leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

104. In the given image, the marked part of the pancreas is mainly supplied by which of the following arteries?

* Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

* Arteria pancreatica magna

* Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the head of the pancreas. It is supplied by both the superior and inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

Superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries are branches of the gastroduodenal artery from the celiac trunk. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries are branches of the superior mesenteric artery.

The uncinate process of the pancreas is supplied by the inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

The body and tail of the pancreas are mainly supplied by the branches of the splenic artery:

* Dorsal pancreatic artery

* Greater pancreatic artery (Arteria pancreatica magna)

* Artery to the tail of the pancreas

questions.text: 105. A 32-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding his diagnosis?

choices.text: Most commonly seen in upper eyelid

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of chronic painless swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish nodule in the lid is suggestive of chalazion. Infection of chalazion leads to hordeolum internum. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst.

They are most commonly seen in the upper eyelid than the lower eyelid because the upper eyelid has more meibomian glands. 

Histopathology shows a lipogranulomatous picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells.

Most of the patients present with gradually enlarging painless rounded nodules, watering of the eyes, blurring of vision, and blepharitis. Rosacea is associated with multiple and recurrent chalazia. 

A recurrent chalazion should be biopsied to exclude malignant transformation. In elderly patients, malignant transformation to meibomian gland adenocarcinoma can be occasionally. 

Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. 

Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective.

Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

Other options:

External hordeolum is also known as stye, is an acute suppurative inflammation of the lash follicle. It is a painful condition, with swelling of the eyelids, photophobia, and mild watering. Given below is an image of the external hordeolum.

According to the KDIGO classification, the stage of this patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) is G4.

CKD is a spectrum of pathophysiological processes resulting in abnormal kidney function, with a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). questions.text:
107. A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia. Examinations reveal a tender retroverted uterus along with a cobblestone feel of the uterosacral ligaments. There are blue-black puckered, tender spots in the posterior and lateral fornices. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the treatment modalities for this condition?

LUNA- Laser uterosacral nerve ablation

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge
Pulsatile GnRH for atrophy of lesions
Mirena IUCD for dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis and continuous GnRH administration is used in this condition as it causes endometrial atrophy. It can be given IV and intranasally. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. It is a benign condition but it is locally invasive and it shows the malignant transformation.

Some of the common sites of endometriosis are ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, rectovaginal septum, and sigmoid colon. 

Patients with endometriosis mainly present with progressively increasing secondary dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, infertility, dyspareunia, and chronic pelvic pain.

MRI is the diagnostic tool, it shows the characteristic hyperintensity on T1 weighted images and hypointensity on T2 weighted images. Laparoscopy confirms the diagnosis.

Medical management of endometriosis:

* Gestrinone is an anti-estrogenic, anti-progestational, and mildly anabolic drug that reduces sex-hormone-binding globulin to release free testosterone. It also decreases the LH surge. It causes regression of lesions and amenorrhea. It is a 19-nortestosterone derivative similar to danazol, but with fewer side effects. 

* Combined oral contraceptives are used for symptom control and alleviating disease. These also cause menstrual cycle regulation and delay pregnancy. 

* Oral progestogens exert an anti-estrogenic effect and cause decidualization and endometrial atrophy. This causes disease regression. It doesn't prevent ovulation, thus is suitable for women who are trying to conceive. 

* Mirena IUCDs reduce dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. It is a single-sitting treatment with minimal side effects. 

* Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are anti-estrogens given for disease regression. 

* Anti-inflammatory drugs like mefenamic acid and naproxen relieve dysmenorrhea.

Therapeutic procedures:

* Aspiration of peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac removes PGE2, relieves dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and improves fertility 

* Destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser, or CO2 vaporization can be attempted. 

* Larger lesions and chocolate cysts can be excised. 

* Laparoscopic breaking of adhesions relieves dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. It also restores tubal patency and improves ovulation. Pre-sacral neurectomy can be done simultaneously. 

* Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.



Pearl PM1005: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

* Ovarian endometriosis.

* Chocolate cyst of the ovary.

* Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.

* Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

* Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.

* Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.

* Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).

* Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.

* Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: 109. A 35-year-old female patient with multiple sclerosis presents with the complaints of visual difficulties and headache. Ophthalmologic examination of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the examination findings point towards a diagnosis of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO).

The site of lesion in the case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side.

As seen in the image above, on the left gaze, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. This means that the lesion is in the right MLF. The right gaze is normal. 

A few causes of INO include demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, Guillian Barre syndrome), strokes, and tumors.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements.

The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye.

The second output is to the MLF which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction.

These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. 

The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.





Features of unilateral INO include

* Straight gaze in the primary position of the eyes

* Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye with the contralateral eye having nystagmus on abduction

* Looking at the ipsilateral side has no gaze issues

* Convergence may be intact if the lesion is anterior and discrete.

Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye for both sides.

Other options: 

 

Option B - Cranial nerve VI palsy is characterized by double vision, esotropia, and limitation of abduction on the same side of the lesion. The affected eye would have normal adduction. The following image shows a left cranial nerve VI palsy.



Option C - Vertical gaze palsy is seen in Parinaud syndrome. It is characterized by supranuclear upgaze and downgaze palsy on the saccadic movement of the eye, impaired convergence, lid retraction, and convergence-retraction nystagmus. 

 

Option D - Cranial nerve IV palsy is characterized by ipsilateral hypertropia, extorsion, limitation of depression, and a compensatory head posture (depressed chin).

questions.text: 110. A middle-aged male patient presents to the emergency department with hypotension, palpitations, nausea, vomiting, and absence of knee jerk. Upon eliciting the history, he mentions that 2 hours back, he had consumed seeds of the plant shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this poisoning?

choices.text: The root of the plant resembles horse-radish root.
The plant is also called as 'bish', 'bikh' or 'mitha zaher'.
'Hippus,' which is the alternate opening and closure of eyelids, is a characteristic feature.

questions.solution:
Hippus, i.e. alternate dilatation and constriction of pupils, followed by complete dilation, is a characteristic feature.

The causative plant is aconite. It is also called 'bish', 'bikh', or 'mitha zaher'. It is a cardiac poison. The root resembles a horse-radish root.

Signs and symptoms

Symptoms generally appear within 30 to 90 minutes after ingestion of the poison and last up to approximately 30 hours. 

Some of the typical features of aconitine poisoning:

* Cardiovascular – Palpitation, hypotension, ventricular ectopics/ arrhythmias

* Gastrointestinal – Nausea, salivation, pain in the stomach, vomiting, and diarrhea

* Neurological – Paraesthesia, tingling, and numbness in the lips, mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Followed by profuse sweating, weakness impending paralysis of the extremities and/or seizures.

* Deep tendon reflexes may be absent.

* Eye – There may be difficulty in vision due to hippus, which means initially there is alternate dilatation and constriction of pupils, followed by complete dilation.

* The conscious state of the victim may also be reduced.

* Hypertensive, sustained, ventricular tachyarrhythmias are the direct cause of death. Manifestations of acidosis and hypokalemia are also often seen.

 

The images below show the aconite plant, seeds, and root, respectively.

questions.text: 111. A young patient visits your psychiatric OPD with the complaint that he has been seeing a person who looks exactly like him and wears similar clothes and has been following him around for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is suffering from doppelganger syndrome.

Doppelganger syndrome is a delusion of subjective doubles, where the person feels that he/she has his/her own impostor (doppelganger). 

Other Delusional Misidentification Syndromes:

Fregoli syndrome (Option B) is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Othello syndrome (Option C) is a rare psychiatric condition where a person has morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy and suspects a faithful partner of infidelity.

Capgras syndrome (Option D) is a delusion where a person believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: This is a very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Pearl PM0264: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: 113. On examination of a 26-year-old man, tachycardia was observed during inspiration. The doctor told him that it is respiratory sinus arrhythmia. Which of the following mechanism explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The above mechanism is explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

Tachycardia, in response to increased venous return, is suggestive of Bainbridge reflex. During inspiration, there is an increased venous return due to reduced intrathoracic pressure. This leads to right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria transmit the afferent signals via the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. The efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to result in tachycardia and increase the strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option B: Bezold–Jarisch reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing. It is seen in cases of myocardial ischemia and reperfusion due to the increased synthesis of oxygen free radicals. 

Option C: Cushing reflex: When there is increased intracranial pressure, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. 

Option D: J reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) due to hyperinflation of the lung causes reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia and hypotension.

questions.text: 114. A patient came to the hospital in an agitated state and on examination, his BP was 98/66 mm Hg and respiratory rate was 28/min. He is a chronic asthma patient who has been on theophylline for a long time. His medical history shows the addition of a few new drugs 4 weeks ago for his other ailments like chronic gout, cough and peptic ulcer disease. Identify the drug which does not seem responsible for his present condition.
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is not responsible for this patient's agitation and low blood pressure as it increases theophylline's clearance by enzyme induction.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver and these drugs- erythromycin, cimetidine, and allopurinol inhibit CYP1A2, thereby decreasing the clearance of theophylline leading to agitation and hypotension. A dose reduction of theophylline may be necessary with these drugs.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline are:

* Drugs - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast

* Congestive heart failure

* Liver disease

* Pneumonia

* Viral infection and vaccination

* High-carbohydrate diet

* Old age

Factors that Increase the clearance of theophylline are:

* Enzyme induction (mainly CYP1A2) by coadministered drugs (e.g. rifampicin, barbiturates, ethanol)

* Smoking (tobacco, marijuana) via CYP1A2 induction

* High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet

* Barbecued meat.

Agitation and hypotension occur at concentrations > 25 micrograms/ml, while delirium occurs when levels rise to> 30 micrograms/ml. Arrhythmias and convulsions occur at concentrations of theophylline >35 microgram/ml.

questions.text:
115. Which of the following features are typically associated with delirium?

* Impaired consciousness

* Sundowning

* Normal EEG

* Carphologia or floccillation

* Autonomic Dysfunction
questions.solution:
Delirium is associated with impaired consciousness, carphologia or floccillation, autonomic dysfunction, sundowning, and an abnormal EEG. 

Delirium is characterized by

* An acute decline in the level of awareness 

* Global impairment of cognitive functions (particularly attention)

It also involves

* Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations

* Abnormal psychomotor activity

* Sleep cycle impairment

* Factor VII deficiency - Autosomal recessive

* Factor VIII deficiency - X-linked recessive

* Factor IX deficiency - X-linked recessive

* Factor X deficiency - Autosomal dominant
questions.solution:
The correctly matched conditions with their mode of inheritance are 2, 3, and 4.

Factors VIII and IX deficiencies are inherited as X-linked recessive traits, whereas factors V, VII, and X deficiencies are inherited as autosomal recessive traits.

Factors VIII and IX deficiencies are also known as hemophilia A and B, respectively.

Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable. Mild disease usually presents as bleeding following major trauma. Moderate to severe disease presents as bleeding into the joints (hemarthrosis), soft tissues, and muscles after minor trauma or spontaneously.

These patients usually have a normal bleeding time and platelet counts. The diagnosis can be made only after specific determination of FVIII or FIX clotting activity.

Factor replacement therapy is the treatment of choice either after a bleeding episode or prophylactically.

questions.text: 117. Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALToma).

Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by chronic and persistent inflammation of the salivary glands. Initially, there is a polyclonal immune reaction, but additional mutations acquired over time may lead to the development of B-cells which can multiply even in the absence of growth signals. This is the point at which marginal zone lymphoma develops. Recent studies have shown that patients with Sjögren's syndrome are also at an increased risk for multiple myeloma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein exocrine glands such as lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can occur in isolation or secondary to other systemic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, limited systemic sclerosis, and SLE. 

The patients usually present with drying of the mouth, difficulty in swallowing, and parotid gland enlargement. Ocular involvement may present as a gritty feeling beneath the eyelids. The workup includes the Schirmer test to determine the extent of tear production in the eyes, salivary flow tests, and serum investigations to detect specific antibodies, like anti-Ro and anti-La.  The presence of CD4+ cells on the labial biopsy confirms Sjögren's syndrome.

* Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA

* Primary biliary cirrhosis

* Immune complex-mediated

* Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura

* Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia

* Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: 118. A newborn baby was brought to the dermatology department. His mother says blisters are formed at the site of handling as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

A newborn with trauma-related bullae and vesicles at the site of handling over knees and feet points towards the diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a type of blistering disease. It occurs due to the mutation in the keratin gene (KRT5 or KRT14) encoding for keratin 5 or 14 expressed in the basal cell layer. This mutation causes the production of defective intermediate filaments. This makes epidermal basal cells fragile and subsequently causes blisters on physical pressure. The separation in EBS is within the epidermis (basal cell layer). 

The child is affected at birth and caregivers present the baby with blisters on the hands, elbows, feet, and ankle. More blisters will appear as the baby starts crawling. 

Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of mechano-bullous diseases in which blisters develop in areas of mechanical trauma. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa:

* Epidermolysis bullosa simplex -  defect in K5/K14.

* Junctional epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in laminin.

* Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in collagen-7.

Other options:

Option B- Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by large, tense subepidermal bullae in the groin, axilla, and flexors of the forearm. Most frequently they occur in the elderly population.



Option C- Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by flaccid bullae. They rupture as soon as they appear and crusting occurs. Most frequently they occur in adults of age 40 to 50 years. It shows positive Nikolsky sign.



Option D- Cicatricial pemphigoid is also known as mucous membrane pemphigoid. It is characterized by vesicles that rupture quickly and form ulcers. These are usually seen in mucous membranes like conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Most frequently they occur in older women.

questions.text: 120. A stain present on the clothes of a murder victim is being examined. The benzidine test is positive. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The stain is confirmed as a blood stain
The presence of blood is ruled out

questions.solution:
Since the preliminary benzidine test for blood stains is positive, the next step is to do a definitive spectroscopic test to confirm the presence of blood in the stain.

Benzidine test is the best preliminary test for blood, and it detects blood when present in a dilution of one part of blood in three lakhs. This test uses the peroxidase activity of the blood to change the colour of the reagent. A dark blue colour is produced by adding a drop of a saturated solution of benzidine in glacial acetic acid and then a drop of hydrogen peroxide. A positive reaction is given by recent, old blood stains, blood that has been exposed to heat or cold, and blood stains treated with cleaning agents.

A positive reaction is not proof of the presence of blood (Option A), but a negative reaction rules out the presence of blood (Option B). A False positive reaction is obtained from substances like pus, saliva, milk, rust, bacteria, etc. The phenolphthalein test or Kastle–Meyer test (Option D) is also a preliminary test that works on the same principle as the benzidine test. Here the colour changes to pink in a positive reaction.

The spectroscopic test is the most definitive test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains. It is based on the property of blood pigments to absorb rays from the spectrum. Less than 0.1 mg of blood is sufficient for this test. The blood stain is dissolved in water, normal saline, or diluted ammonia, and placed in a small glass tube, which is then kept between the spectroscope and the light source.

The extract of the blood must be diluted and filtered if it is turbid. The solution of the blood has the property of absorbing some of the rays from the spectrum, producing characteristic dark absorption bands, which vary with the type of blood pigment present.

* Teichmann’s hemin crystal test

* Spectroscopic test

questions.text:
121. A 27-year-old woman presents with dry cough and mild fever for 5 days and musculoskeletal pain for one week. Examination reveals increased respiratory rate and skin lesions all over her body as shown below. Other findings are given below. What is the most effective drug for this condition?

Temperature: 37.8 degrees

Pulse rate: 98 bpm

Blood pressure: 100/70mmHg

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation

Bronchoalveolar lavage culture shows a fried egg appearance
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards pneumonia whereas the constitutional symptoms, patchy consolidation on chest Xray and fried egg appearance on culture is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Azithromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of M. pneumonia.

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia, primary atypical pneumonia, and walking pneumonia. Other bacterial causes of atypical community-acquired pneumonia are Chlamydia pneumonia and Legionella.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat and fever.

It is also can present with extrapulmonary manifestations including erythema multiforme/Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain Barre syndrome, and transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation with thickened bronchial markings and subsegmental atelectasis.

Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance (central opaque granular area of growth sorrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone) on PPLO agar. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. 

Azithromycin is the most effective drug for management. Other drugs used are doxycycline, clarithromycin, erythromycin, moxifloxacin, levofloxacin, gemifloxacin.

Other options:

Options A and B: Amoxicillin and Cefotaxime are beta-lactam antibiotics (cell-wall synthesis inhibitors), hence they are not effective on M.pneumoniae as they lack a cell wall.

questions.text: 122. A 60-year-old man with long-standing diabetes is posted for extracapsular cataract extraction. After primary capsulorhexis, the given lens is handed to the surgeon for implantation. Identify the incorrect statement regarding it.

It is inserted in the anterior chamber, in front of the iris

questions.solution:
The given image is of a modified C-loop type of intraocular lens. It is inserted in the posterior chamber, behind the iris. 

Modified C-loop is a type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL). questions.text: 123. A young man presented with severe muscle weakness and drooping of eyelids. The symptoms worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest. Chest X-ray revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Biopsy of this mass would most likely reveal which of the following pathologic changes?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is associated with thymic hyperplasia.

Myasthenia gravis is an acquired autoimmune disease characterized by abnormal muscular fatigability that typically worsens with exertion and towards the end of the day. It most commonly involves the extraocular muscles causing diplopia and ptosis.

It is caused due to circulating autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor at the myoneural junction. In about 30% of the patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis, and about 10% have thymoma. 

The thymus normally contains small numbers of myoid cells, stromal cells that express skeletal muscle antigens. In both thymoma and thymic hyperplasia, the normal thymic function is disrupted leading to autoimmunity against ACh receptors expressed on thymic myoid cells. 

Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.

questions.text: 124. The peripheral smear of a patient reveals the following finding (indicated by the arrow). The use of which of the following tubes for sample collection is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The image shows platelet clumping. It is seen in blood samples collected with EDTA as the anticoagulant.

EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG).

When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate (sky blue) or heparin (green) collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample. Sample collected in a red tube cannot be used for peripheral smear preparation.

questions.text: 125. An autopsy was done on a patient who died from a neurodegenerative disease. The pathological specimen from his brain is shown below. What does the structure marked in the image comprise?
questions.solution:
The given image is a histological sample showing neurons with a Lewy body. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies that stain positive with periodic acid-Schiff. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease.

Option B: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. 

Option D: Prion proteins deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques.

questions.text: 126. Voyeurism is punished under
questions.solution:
Voyeurism is punishable under BNS Sec 77 (354C IPC) with imprisonment of not less than 1 year, which may extend upto 3 years. For the second and subsequent offenses imprisonment of 3-7 years is given.

During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

questions.text: 128. A 23-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department complaining of depression and loneliness. History taking reveals that he does not engage in any social activity because he’s afraid of being rejected. Identify the likely personality disorder in this patient:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient does not engage in social activities due to fear of being rejected.

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection leading to socially withdrawn lives, low levels of energy, easy fatigability, lack of enthusiasm, and inability to enjoy life. Individuals with avoidant personality disorder exhibit social withdrawal but possess a strong desire to engage in activities, a characteristic that differentiates them from those with schizoid personality disorder, who do not share this inclination.

Other options:

Option B: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by unwarranted suspicion, hypersensi­tivity, jealousy, envy, rigidity, excessive self-importance, and a tendency to blame and ascribe evil motives to others.

 Option C: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by shyness, oversensitivity, seclusive­ ness, avoidance of close or competitive relationships, eccentric­ity, no loss of capacity to recognize reality, daydreaming, and an ability to express hostility and aggression.

 Option D: Antisocial personal­ity disorder covers persons in conflict with society. They are incapable of loyalty, selfish, callous, irresponsible, impulsive, and unable to feel guilt or learn from experience; they have low levels of frustration tolerance and a tendency to blame others.
