questions.text: 129. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the ER with a history of colicky abdominal pain that has worsened over the past few hours. On examination, the following clinical finding is noted. All of the following are true about this condition except?

choices.text: Empty left iliac fossa indicates positive Sign of Dance
The patient may have bilious vomiting
Ileocolic junction is the most common site of involvement
Meckel's diverticulum is a possible lead point

questions.solution:
An acute abdomen with a sausage-shaped mass with its concavity towards the umbilicus is one of the characteristic findings in a patient with intussusception. An empty right-iliac fossa in this condition is called the Sign of Dance.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. Patients present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools. Vomiting may not begin later and with time, may be bile-stained (Option B).

Intussusception is one of the common causes of intestinal obstruction in a paediatric patient. Ileo-colic junction is the most common site of involvement (Option C). The condition may arise due to the presence of lead points as seen in enlarged submucosal Payer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum (Option D), intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts.

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the pathognomonic target sign/bull's eye sign (shown below).



Treatment of intussusception includes hydrostatic reduction by enema using contrast material or air. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences after hydrostatic reduction.

questions.text: 130. The autopsy of a 1-year-old child who died of congestive cardiac failure revealed multiple tumors of the heart located in the ventricles. What is the characteristic histopathologic finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and histological slide showing spider cells are suggestive of cardiac rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, cardiac rhabdomyomas are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Histologic processing of the sample usually removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands. These strands stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This gives an appearance that resembles a spider and is hence referred to as spider cells.

Rhabdomyomas are mostly seen in the first year of life. They are discovered when there is an obstruction to a valvular orifice or cardiac chamber. Approximately half the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations. The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are usually multiple and appear in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas and not true neoplasms.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.



Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the adult heart. Unlike rhabdomyomas, they are usually single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells (Option A) embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells(Option B). Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Kulchitsky cells (Option D) are neuroendocrine progenitor cells that lines the bronchial epithelium and give rise to small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: 131. A 30-year-old tourist is on a road trip in the Philippines where he consumes food from the roadside vendors. The next day he develops loose stools and abdominal pain. Which of the following bacteria and their toxins which act by increasing cGMP, can be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The heat-stable toxin of Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) acts by increasing cGMP.

Tourist from developed countries visiting endemic areas often suffers from ETEC diarrhea, a condition known as Traveller's diarrhea. Entero-toxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of Traveller’s Diarrhoea. Colonization factor antigens promote adherence of ETEC to epithelial cells of the small bowel.

Some strains of ETEC produce the heat-stable enterotoxin, which activates guanylyl cyclase in enteric epithelial cells and increases cGMP. This increases fluid secretion.

Some strains of ETEC produce a heat-labile enterotoxin. It attaches to the GM1 ganglioside in the apical membrane of enterocytes and activates adenylyl cyclase. This markedly increases the local concentration of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). This result is intense and prolonged hypersecretion of water and chlorides, and inhibits reabsorption of sodium.

questions.text: 132. A 10-year-old boy who presented with hepatomegaly, tremors, poor coordination, and choreoathetosis was diagnosed with Wilson's disease. Where does the underlying defect likely lie in this condition?
questions.solution:
In Wilson's disease, there is a mutation of the ATP7B gene. The likely underlying defect resulting from this mutation is in the excretion of copper into bile.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene, which codes for the enzyme copper-transporting ATPase present on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

In general, the free copper is taken up by hepatocytes and incorporated to form ceruloplasmin gets released into the bloodstream and accounts for 90% to 95% of plasma copper. Excess hepatic copper gets transported into the bile and eventually excreted in the feces.

The deficiency of the ATP7B gene impairs copper transport into the bile, its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and secretion of ceruloplasmin into the blood. This results in a decrease in circulating ceruloplasmin levels and increased levels of hepatic copper. Total serum copper level may be decreased due to the deficiency in ceruloplasmin.

The excessive accumulation of copper injures the hepatocytes. This in turn releases the non-ceruloplasmin-bound copper into the bloodstream, which later gets deposited in tissues like the basal ganglia of the brain and the cornea. This results in behavioral disturbances and extrapyramidal symptoms and the characteristic KF ring that is seen on slit-lamp examination. There is a marked compensatory urinary copper excretion. However, these levels do not suffice to prevent the deposition of copper in tissues.

questions.text: 133. A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of a chronic cough and weight loss. He has a 30-pack-years smoking history. Bronchoscopy and biopsy show the findings below. Which of the following is false about this patient's condition?

choices.text: CD56 is expressed by these tumour cells
Smokers are strongly predisposed to this condition
Hypercalcemia may be associated with this condition
Keratinization and squamous pearls can be seen in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. CD56 is not expressed by squamous cell carcinoma, it is a marker for small cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is most commonly found in men and is strongly associated with smoking. 

Squamous cell carcinoma predominantly arises in the central segmental or subsegmental bronchi. The tumor may grow into the bronchial lumen and produce an intraluminal mass. In certain cases, the bronchial obstruction may lead to atelectasis or infection. The tumor may penetrate the wall of the bronchus and infiltrate the peribronchial tissue into the carina or the mediastinum. 

This tumor may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, the most common is hypercalcemia. The symptoms could include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, lethargy, polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration.

Squamous metaplasia and dysplasia often precede frank squamous cell carcinoma. Carcinoma in-situ persists for many years and this may often be recognized on cytologic smears or in BAL fluid or brushings.

Gross appearance: The tissue is grey-white, firm, with areas of necrosis and hemorrhages. Red or yellow-white mottling and softening may be seen. The necrotic foci may cavitate. 

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of keratinization and intercellular bridges. Keratinization can be seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm.

questions.text: 134. A primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with watery discharge per vagina and regular contractions. Physical examination reveals an adequately dilated and effaced cervix with rupture of membranes. Presentation is vertex, but labor stops progressing after the head has appeared in the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist in the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region), while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:



Other options-

Option (A): Pinard maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

* The middle and index fingers are carried up to the popliteal fossa.

* Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.



Option (B): Lovset maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

This technique is demonstrated in the images below-



Option (C): Modified Prague’s maneuver(shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

* Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction



 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

* Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.

* When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.

* Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.



 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

* Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.

* Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.

* Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.

* Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.

* Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.



 

Mnemonic:

* Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)

* Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text:
135. A patient was tested for CFTR gene mutations and was found to be positive. Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with CFTR gene mutation?

* Morphologically abnormal sweat glands

* Squamous metaplasia of pancreas

* Congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens

* Focal biliary cirrhosis
questions.solution:
CFTR gene mutations result in cystic fibrosis. In all variants of cystic fibrosis, the sweat glands are morphologically unaffected.

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal reccessive disorder of ion transport that affects fluid secretion in exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining. It is caused primarily due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene which serves as an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. This leads to abnormally viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages, resulting in recurrent infections, pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malnutrition, hepatic cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, and male infertility.

Impaired fat absorption due to the loss of pancreatic exocrine secretion and the resultant avitaminosis A can contribute to squamous metaplasia of the lining epithelium of the pancreas. Associated squamous metaplasia of the salivary gland may also be found.

Focal biliary cirrhosis may occur, which may progress to involve the whole liver, resulting in diffuse hepatic nodularity.

Azoospermia and infertility are seen in most male patients. Congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens is commonly seen in these patients. In some patients, bilateral absence of the vas deferens may be the only feature suggesting an underlying CFTR mutation.

questions.text: 136. Which of the following statements is false about conditions required for acute radiation syndrome?

choices.text: Radiation dose must be large i.e greater than 70 rads.
The dose must be mostly internal.
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects.
The dose must have been delivered in a short time.

questions.solution:
Acute radiation syndrome after deposition of radioactive materials inside the body is extremely rare. The dose must be external.

Acute radiation syndrome, also called radiation toxicity or radiation sickness, is an acute illness caused by irradiation of the entire body by a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. The major cause of this syndrome is the depletion of immature parenchymal stem cells in specific tissues.

Stages of Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

The prodromal phase: This phase is marked by non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.

Latent phase: The patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.

Manifest illness phase: Symptoms depend the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.

Recovery phase or Death: The recovery phase is seen after the manifest stage when the patient recovers from the acute exposure. The time taken for recovery depends on the severity of the injury and the organ system affected.

questions.text:
137. A 20-year-old male patient complained of pain after an injury to his left knee while playing football. MRI showed a bucket-handle tear of the medial meniscus. The anterior cruciate ligament was intact. Which of the following radiographic findings best describes this condition?

(PCL- posterior cruciate ligament)
questions.solution:
The double PCL sign is the radiographic finding seen on a sagittal MRI image in a bucket-handle medial meniscal tear with an intact anterior cruciate ligament.

Double PCL sign: Here, the bucket handle fragment of the torn meniscus is seen as a low-signal structure lying parallel to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), mimicking a second smaller PCL.

A bucket-handle tear occurs when there is a vertical split in the meniscus, and the separated fragment of the meniscus remains attached in the front and back. The medial meniscus is involved in 80% of the cases. 

An intact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is required to appreciate the double PCL sign in medial meniscal tears as it prevents the flipped meniscal fragment from further lateral movement.

In very few cases, the double PCL sign is seen with bucket-handle tears involving the lateral meniscus.



Meniscal tears can be horizontal and vertical.

Horizontal tears are frequently degenerative in nature and asymptomatic. Joint fluid may escape through this tear and form a parameniscal cyst.

Vertical tears can be of two types: longitudinal and radial.

Longitudinal tears:

* They lie within the substance of the menisci and track circumferentially.

* It usually involves the periphery of the meniscus, where the blood supply is better, and may heal spontaneously.

Radial tears:

* It extends radially from the free edges into the meniscus, and it can be of several forms.

* Parrot -beak tear: Small oblique slit-like radial tear

* Ghost meniscus sign: It refers to the MRI appearance of a complete radial tear, usually involving the posterior root of the meniscus. It is so called because the meniscus disappears and then reappears like a "ghost" on consecutive sagittal sequences. 

Note: The double Oreo cookie sign is seen in injuries to the glenoid labrum. (option D)

questions.text: 138. An 18-year-old patient comes with swelling of face and lips after he heard the passing of his dog as shown in the image. He was administered icatibant. What is the likely mechanism of action of the drug prescribed to the boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hereditary angioedema.

Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema.

The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. 

Both icatibant and ecallantide are administered subcutaneously.

A common side effect is a local reaction at the injection site (redness, bruising, swelling, burning, itching, etc.). Other side effects include fever, elevated transaminase, dizziness, nausea, headache, or rash. 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is due to an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitors. Patients with HAE usually present with episodic attacks that begin during childhood that became more severe during adolescence.

There may be symptoms before the episodes occur, such as sudden mood changes, anxiety, sensory changes, or exhaustion may also occur for several hours. In one-third of patients, attacks are precipitated by trauma-like pressure. 

Symptoms are referable to 3 prominent sites:

* Subcutaneous tissues like face, hands, arms, legs, genitals, and buttocks

* Abdominal organs like the stomach, intestines, bladder, and kidneys. This manifests as vomiting, diarrhea, or paroxysmal colicky pain

* The upper airway (larynx) and tongue, which results in laryngeal edema and upper airway obstruction

The swelling is usually unresponsive to antihistamines.

Recent Update: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently approved another plasma kallikrein inhibitor, berotralstat, as the first oral drug for the prevention and treatment of hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: 139. A 60-year-old man presented with a T3 tumor of the glottis with invasion into the paraglottic space. All of the following form the boundaries of this space, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned structures form the boundaries of paraglottic space, except the arcuate lines which form the superior and inferior borders of Reinke's space.

Paraglottic space has the following boundaries:

* Superior - Para-glottic space is continuous with the pre-epiglottic space

* Posterior - Piriform fossa

* Lateral - Thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane

* Medial - Quadrangular membrane in the upper part and conus elasticus in the lower part

It consists of the adipose tissue, internal laryngeal nerve, laryngeal ventricle, and saccule.

Tumors of the glottis are classified as T3 when the growth is limited to the larynx with fixation of vocal cords or thyroid cartilage erosion or invasion into the paraglottic space.

Pre-epiglottic space of Boyer lies anterior to the epiglottis. Its relations are as follows:

* Superior - Hyoepiglottic membrane.

* Inferior - Thyroepiglottic ligament.

* Anterior - Thyrohyoid membrane.

* Posterior - Epiglottis.

* Lateral - Greater cornua of the hyoid bone in the upper part, continuous with the paraglottic space in the lower part.



Reinke's space lies under the epithelium of vocal cords. It has the following boundaries :

* Superior and inferior - Arcuate lines

* Anterior - Anterior commissure

* Posterior - Vocal process of arytenoid

questions.text:
140. Which of the following test(s) is/are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant ?

* Rideal-Walker test

* Chick Martin test

* Kelsey-Sykes test

* In-use test
questions.solution:
All of the above tests are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant.

The Rideal-Walker test helps in determining the phenol co-efficient (PC) which indicates the power of a disinfectant. A PC value of more than 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. It is only of historical value. St. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi were the organisms that were traditionally used for this test.

Chick Martin test: This is a modification of Rideal-Walker test in which the disinfectants acts in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions.

Kelsey-Sykes test (capacity test): It tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly. This is used now.

In-use test: It determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use. This is used now.

questions.text: 141. A middle-aged man is being evaluated for epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few weeks. He also gives a history of occasional black discoloration of the stools. A barium study was done for the patient. Which of the following findings on barium study would indicate that the ulcer is benign?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric ulcers and the presence of Hampton's lines on barium study would indicate that the gastric ulcer is benign.

Hampton's line is a thin radiolucent line seen at the base of a gastric ulcer in barium studies. It represents the preserved gastric mucosa with undermining of the more vulnerable submucosa. It indicates the benign nature of the gastric ulcer.

Other features of a benign ulcer include:

* The smooth rim of lucency at the base of the ulcer.

* Converging folds

* Round, linear, or oval-shaped ulcer

* Symmetrical, gently sloping ulcer mass.

Difference between benign and malignant gastric ulcer:

Barium swallow findings Benign Malignant
Hampton’s line Present Absent
Extends beyond the gastric wall Yes No
Folds Smooth, even Irregular, nodular, may fuse
Carman meniscus Absent Present
Ulcer shape Round, oval, linear Irregular


Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers. It refers to the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer, nodular mound, and thickened, irregular interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer, loss of mucosal pattern, and incomplete healing.

questions.text:
144. Which of the following statements is/are true about basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal tract?

* They are maximum in the proximal part of the stomach

* It is generated by interstitial cells of Cajal

* Frequency of these waves in the cecum is 8 per minute

* Epinephrine increases the number of spikes and tension

* They fluctuate between −65 mV to −45 mV.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 5 are true regarding basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal system.

Basal electrical rhythm (BER):

The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

* Stomach: 4/min

* Duodenum: 12/min

* Distal ileum: 8/min

* Cecum: 2/min

* Sigmoid colon: 6/min

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

* Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

* Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text:
145. For the detection of a disease, three tests are done one after another. The patient is said to be positive for the disease only if all three tests are positive. Which of the following statements are true regarding this method of testing?

* Increased sensitivity

* Increased specificity

* Increased positive predictive value

* Increased negative predictive value
questions.solution:
When multiple tests are done in series, the specificity is increased. This means there is a reduction in the false positive error rate, leading to improved positive predictive value.

Screening tests are said to have been done in series when a number of tests are performed sequentially, but the next test is done only if the previous test was found to be positive. For example, testing for HIV by serial ELISA.

Screening tests are said to have been done in parallel when the second test is independently performed — regardless of what the first test result was. Both tests are done at the same time to evaluate the same disease. For example, using fasting, post-prandial and HbA1C testing at the same time for a patient suspected to be diabetic.

When tests are done in parallel, the sensitivity increases. This causes a reduction in the false negative error rate, and thus increases the negative predictive value of the combination of tests.

questions.text:
146. A 45-year-old female who has an anal fistula is advised for surgery. She browsed about the surgical procedures and came to know that a few procedures may lead to fecal incontinence. She was worried and asks you about the surgeries that does not lead to this complication. Which among the following surgeries allow sphincter preservation?

* Video-assisted anal fistula treatment.

* Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.

* Flap advancement.

* Fistula tract laser closure.

* Over-the-scope clip.
questions.solution:
The surgeries for anal fistula that allow sphincter preservation are:

* Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.

* Flap advancement.

* Over-the-scope clip.

* Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT)

* Fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC)

Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT) is done at the level of the intersphincteric plane where the internal opening and fistula are disconnected. This is followed by the removal of the residual gland without involving the sphincter complex.

Flap advancement is done for the tracts that are not indurated and adequate intra-anal access can be obtained. The internal opening of the fistula is closed with a well-vascularized flap of anorectal mucosa. This procedure aims at preserving the anatomy and function of the sphincter.

Over-the-scope procedure involves using a nitinol clip and closing the internal opening and disconnecting the external tract. Clip migration and elective removal because of pain are the main complications.

Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT) and fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC) are other procedures that allow sphincter preservation.

A fistulotomy is preferred mainly for intersphincteric fistulae and trans-sphincteric fistulae. Here, all structures lying between the external and internal openings are divided. In fistulectomy, the entire fistula tract is removed by diathermy cautery.

questions.text: 147. Eflapegrastim belongs to which of the given drug class?
questions.solution:
Eflapegrastim is a Recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF).

FDA has recently approved Eflapegrastim to decrease the incidence of infection, in adult patients receiving myelosuppressive anti-cancer drugs. Anti-cancer drugs can frequently cause Myelosuppression, which manifests as febrile neutropenia and increase the risk of recurrent and severe infection in these patients. Thus, recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) class of drugs are given to correct the neutropenia. Examples of G-CSF are eflapegrastim, pegfilgrastim and filgrastim. 

Eflapegrastim binds to G-CSF receptors on myeloid progenitor cells and neutrophils, triggering signalling pathways that control cell differentiation, proliferation, migration and survival. Adverse effects include fatigue, nausea, diarrhoea, bone pain, headache, pyrexia, anaemia, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, and back pain. 

Other options: Recombinant human erythropoietin like Epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa are used in the treatment of anaemias associated with surgery, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions. They increase erythropoiesis.

Recombinant human thrombopoietin like Oprelvekin is used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. It increases thrombopoiesis.

Recombinant human granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor(GM-CSF) like Sargramostim is used for Myeloid reconstitution after bone marrow transplant, Prophylaxis of neutropenia in myelosuppressive chemotherapy and Stem cell mobilization in donor for stem cell transplant.

questions.text: 148. The image shows a graph plotted between the rate of reaction (on the y-axis) and substrate concentration (on the x-axis). Which of the following statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is not seen with monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
The statement claiming adherence to Michaelis-Menten kinetics is incorrect based on this plot.

The given plot shows a sigmoid curve suggestive of the cooperative binding of the enzymes to their substrates. This type of saturation kinetics is explained by the Hill equation. 

Hill equation:

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site. This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by hemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As Michaelis-Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding. Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds. 

Michaelis-Menten Kinetics:

The Michaelis-Menten equation gives the mathematical relationship between initial reaction velocity, v, and substrate concentration [S] which is as given below.

v = Vmax[S]/Km+[S]

where Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2), which is reached at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

A graph showing a hyperbola is suggestive of Michaelis-Menten kinetics of the enzyme, which is as follows.



For enzymes showing Michaelis - Menten kinetics, there is an increase in the rate of reaction, V, with an increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

questions.text:
149. A 23-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and malaise for the last week. He has a low-grade fever and developed jaundice yesterday. He does not have fecal incontinence. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His laboratory evaluation is given below. What is the management for his condition?

IgM Anti-HAV positive
HBsAg negative
HBeAg negative
anti-HBs positive
serum aminotransferases elevated
questions.solution:
This patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and positive IgM- HAV is likely to have acute hepatitis A infection and requires supportive treatment. 

Since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required. 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene. It mostly is of mild nature, with only 0.1% of patients developing fulminant hepatitis.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Low-grade fever may also be present. 

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. 

Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. 

It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other options:

Option B - Antivirals are not needed in HAV. They may be used in hepatitis B or C. 

Option C - Physical isolation is done in hepatitis A patients with fecal incontinence. This patient does not have fecal incontinence. Even then, HAV is excreted in feces in very small amounts. Using gloves to handle fecal matter is sufficient.

Option D - Interferon therapy is useful in the treatment of chronic HCV and HBV infections. They are cytokines that have antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antiproliferative activity.

questions.text: 150. A 46-year-old male presented with abdominal pain, peripheral edema, and ascites. History revealed a loss of appetite, weight loss, and diarrhea. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of gastrin. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed the following appearance involving the fundus and body of the stomach, sparing the antrum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are diagnostic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease, also called hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy is a disorder of the stomach characterized by enlarged rugae (gastric folds). It is caused due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, which is an EGF receptor (EGFR) ligand, and hyperactivation of the epidermal growth factor receptor on gastric epithelial cells.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

The condition is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds as shown below. The antrum is usually spared.



Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.



Other options:

Option a: Infiltrative type of gastric adenocarcinoma is characterized by a thickened gastric wall and partial loss of rugal folds. These changes impart a leather bottle appearance, termed linitis plastica.

Option b: Zollinger–ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor. The tumors are found in the small intestine or pancreas. increased gastrin secretion causes, changes in gastric wall, characterized by an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Opition d: Whipple disease is an intestinal disease characterized by the triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. The disease is caused due to accumulation of bacteria-laden macrophages within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes leading to lymphatic obstruction. Impaired lymphatic drainage causes malabsorption.

questions.text:
151. A 60-year-old obese woman was planned for CECT abdomen with urografin. She had presented with signs of severe dehydration, raised serum creatinine levels, and features of diabetic nephropathy. Which among the following is not a risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy in this patient?

CECT - Contrast-enhanced computed tomography
questions.solution:
Obesity is not a risk factor for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in this patient. All the other factors are risk factors for CIN making this patient unfit for a CECT.

Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a 25% or 0.5 mg/dL increase from the baseline value of serum creatinine within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. It occurs due to tubular damage and as a result, the patient develops non-oliguric transient nephropathy.

Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy:

Patient-related

Procedure-related
  • eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration
  • eGFR <45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration
  • Patient conditions that increase the risk:
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Dehydration
    • Congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3–4) and low LVEF
    • Recent myocardial infarction (<24 h)
    • Intra-aortic balloon pump
    • Peri-procedural hypotension
    • Low hematocrit level
    • Age over 70
    • Concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs
    • Known or suspected acute renal failure

 

  
  • Intra-arterial administration of contrast medium
  • High-osmolality agents (Urografin)
  • Large doses of contrast medium
  • Multiple contrast medium administrations within a few days

 


 Side effects of iodinated contrast material include:

* Idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction - patient develops bronchospasm and hypotension

* Dose-dependent side effect – contrast-induced nephropathy seen especially with the use of high osmolar agents

Prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy:

* IV fluids (isotonic saline or sodium bicarbonate) started 1 hour before and continued for at least 3-6 hours after the procedure

* Low volume low osmolar contrast should be used

* N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure 

Note: In a patient on metformin, having deranged RFT, metformin must be stopped before administering the contrast. Otherwise, it can precipitate lactic acidosis.

  Iodinated contrast materials  
Types Ionic  Non-ionic
Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer
Osmolarity

1400- 1600 mOsm (Not preferred due to high osmolarity)

Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples 

Diatrizoate (Urograffin)

questions.text:
152. A 21-year-old, 32-week pregnant woman presents with complaints of right-sided flank pain and fever with chills and vomiting for 1 day. Her BP is 120/66 mmHg. Examination reveals right costovertebral angle tenderness. The abdomen is non-tender without any contractions. Her lab reports are given below. What is the possible diagnosis?

CBC 
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Platelet count 1,35,000/mm3
Urine analysis 
Nitrites Positive
WBC  200/hpf
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis.

Acute pyelonephritis is the infection of the renal parenchyma. It is more frequent in the second half of pregnancy and presents as fever, chills, aching pain in the lumbar region, and costovertebral angle tenderness.

Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism. Klebsiella pneumoniae, Enterobacter and Proteus species, group B Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus aureus are other rare causes.

Urinalysis would be positive for nitrite and show increased WBCs. Treatment involves hospitalization for the administration of intravenous fluids with antibiotics. 

Other options:

Option B - In appendicitis, persistent abdominal pain and tenderness are the most common findings. Right lower quadrant pain is the most frequently seen, but pain migrates upward with appendiceal displacement due to the gravid uterus. Costovertebral angle tenderness and abnormal findings of urinalysis, which are seen in the given case, are not associated with appendicitis.

Option C - HELLP syndrome is a rare complication of pre-eclampsia. This refers to hemolysis (H), elevated liver (EL) enzyme levels, and low platelet (LP) count (<100,000/mm3). Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is the hallmark of the triad of HELLP syndrome. In the given case, the patient has normal BP and platelet count, which rules out this option.

Option D - Abruptio placentae refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus. Placental abruption may be either concealed (when blood accumulates behind the placenta) or revealed (when blood escapes through the cervix). Patients with placental abruption present with abdominal pain and a tense, tender uterus with contractions, which is not consistent with the findings in the given case.

questions.text:
153. Match the following spinal deformity with their mechanism

  1. Knuckle
  2. Gibbus
  3. Kyphosis

A. Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies

B. Collapse of a single vertebra


C. Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels
questions.solution:
The correct match is

Deformity Mechanism
Knuckle Collapse of a single vertebra
Gibbus/Kyphus Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels
Kyphosis Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies




Spinal tuberculosis may present with the following skeletal deformities:

Deformity Mechanism Description
Knuckle Collapse of a single vertebra Prominence of a single spinous process
Gibbus/Kyphus Collapse of 2-3 vertebral levels Sharp posterior angulation
Kyphosis Collapse of anterior vertebral bodies Exaggerated curvature of the vertebral column
Concertina collapse / vertebra plana Collapse of the entire vertebral body Seen in tuberculosis of the central vertebral body


 

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

* Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.

* Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbus.

* Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through anterior longitudinal ligament.

* Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process) is affected.

Clinical features of spinal tuberculosis:

* Back pain, stiffness and reduced movements are the usual early complaints

* Cautious gait - a person with spinal TB will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement

* Pott's paraplegia

* Cold abscess

* Concertina collapse - a type of compression fracture without involvement of the interverterbral disc

* Deformity - kyphus and gibbus (gradually increasing prominence).

questions.text: 154. A young woman came to the gynecologist with complaints of inability to conceive even after regular intercourse. Semen analysis of her partner was unremarkable. Hysterosalpingography revealed the following finding. Which of the following is incorrect about the condition?

choices.text: Functional rudimentary horn can present with hematometra
It occurs due to the failure of normal development of one Mullerian duct
MRI shows banana-like configuration of the uterine cavity
It is a class IV uterine malformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of unicornuate uterus and it is not a class IV uterine malformation, but a class II Mullerian malformation according to the American Fertility Society. Class IV uterine malformation refers to a bicornuate uterus.

The history of infertility and hysterosalpingography(HSG) showing a spindle-shaped or banana-shaped uterine cavity deviated to the left with a patent left fallopian tube suggests a unicornuate uterus. It results from the failure of the normal development of one müllerian duct.  It is associated with increased spontaneous abortion, obstetric complications, and renal abnormalities.

On T2-weighted MR images, the unicornuate uterus demonstrates a curved, elongated uterus with tapering of the fundal segment off the midline. This is known as the banana-like configuration. Normal uterine zonal anatomy is maintained.

If a functional rudimentary horn is present, it usually demonstrates lower signal intensity and might contain endometrial tissue. They have increased chances of endometriosis and hematometra which can be an indication for excision.

Pearl PM1912: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina


A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: 155. An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported in a town between June and September of 2021. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. This exemplifies:
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral Hepatitis A is an example of a point source, multiple exposures type of epidemic.

In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a point source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics are:

  Point source, single exposure Point source, multiple exposures 
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning from an event Sex worker infected with gonorrhea, contaminated well water


Option C- Cyclic trend refers to the appearance of diseases after regular intervals. For example, influenza pandemics occur every 7-10 years, automobile accidents increase during weekends, etc.

Option D- Secular trend refers to the progressive increase or decrease of the occurrence of a disease over a very long period of time. Even though there are short-term fluctuations, it moves in a particular direction over a long period of time. Examples are coronary heart disease, lung cancer and diabetes have an upward trend, while diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio have a declining trend.



Pearl PM0234: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

* Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics

* Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

* Person to person

* Arthropod vector

* Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

* Non-communicable diseases

Pearl PM0507: Investigation of an Epidemic

A) Steps

* Verification of diagnosis

* Confirmation of existence of epidemic

* Defining the population at risk

* Obtaining a map of the area

* Counting the population

* Rapid search for all the cases

* Medical survey

* Epidemiological case sheets

* Searching for more cases

* Data analysis on the basis of time, place and person

* Formulation of hypothesis

* Testing of hypothesis

* Evaluation of ecological factors

* Further investigation of population at risk

* Writing the report

B) Final Epidemic Report

* Background including geography, climate, demography, socio-economic groups, health service organization, surveillance data and normal disease prevalence

* Historical data including previous occurrences of the epidemic, occurrence of any related diseases and discovery of the primary case in present outbreak

* Methodology of investigations including case definition, epidemiological questionnaires, collection and laboratory techniques

* Analysis of data including clinical and epidemiological data, modes of transmission, laboratory data and all their interpretations

* Control measures including strategy definitions, methodology of implementation, evaluation methods and preventive measures

questions.text: 156. All of the following methods of removal of hardness of water cause the precipitation of calcium carbonate except?
questions.solution:
Boiling and the addition of soda ash/ lime remove the hardness of water by the precipitation of calcium carbonate. The base exchange process leads to the precipitation of calcium and magnesium permutit.

Option A: Permutit is a complex chemical compound of sodium, aluminum, and silica that is used in the process of base exchange to remove the temporary and permanent hardness of water. It works on the principle of ion exchange to remove calcium and magnesium from water.

Option B: The addition of soda ash or sodium carbonate can remove temporary as well as permanent hardness and causes the precipitation of calcium carbonate. 

Option C: In Clark's method, lime or calcium hydroxide is added to water also to remove temporary hardness. The lime absorbs the carbon dioxide and causes precipitation of calcium carbonate.

Option D: Boiling the water can remove temporary hardness by precipitating calcium carbonate and expelling carbon dioxide.

Pearl PM1612: Hardness of Water

* Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.

* It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.

* Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 

* Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

* 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.

Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of hardness-producing ion (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300


* Drinking water must be moderately hard

* Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)

* Removal of hardness:

* Boiling: 

* This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.

* Addition of lime: 

* This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.

* Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.

* Base exchange process:

* This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: 157. A 4-year-old child presents with seizures. MRI of the brain revealed cortical tubers. The image below depicts a type of skin lesion seen in this condition. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the image shows confetti skin lesions seen in this condition.

Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is a neurocutaneous syndrome with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. It is due to a mutation in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene, which encodes proteins hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

It presents during childhood with intellectual disability, skin lesions, and seizures. Infants can present with infantile spasms.

Various skin lesions seen in tuberous sclerosis include:

Confetti skin lesions - hypomelanotic macules that are 1-3 mm in diameter that usually appears symmetrically over the distal extremities. 

Facial angiofibromas - reddish nodules seen on the nose and cheeks. Eventually, they join together to form a fleshy growth. It is usually seen between the ages of four to six. It is shown in the image given below:



Periungual fibromas - They are small fibromas or skin nodules seen around finger or toenails in a few patients. The image below shows these lesions:



Shagreen patch - a rough, raised lesion with the consistency of an orange peel. It is usually seen in the lumbosacral region.



Ash leaf macules - hypomelanotic macules that are ≥5 mm, seen on the trunk and extremities as shown in the image below:



There can be involvement of other organ systems as seen by cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis. Involvement of the central nervous system is a hallmark of tuberous sclerosis. These include cortical tuber, retinal lesions, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA).

Surgical resection of SEGA is done in patients with symptoms. Routine antiepileptic therapy can be implemented for seizures. Vigabatrin is used to manage infantile spasms.

Pearl PM2489: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

* Seizures

* Mental retardation

* Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.



The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.



Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.



Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients



Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: 158. On performing a swinging flashlight test, the following finding is noted. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows Marcus Gunn pupil/ relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. Iridoplegia refers to paralysis of the iris sphincter. It would result in the pupil not responding to both ipsilateral and contralateral stimulus, not just the ipsilateral one, as seen in RAPD.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease. It also occurs in severe retinal disease. 

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) results in sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye and a fundus examination showing a pale retina with a cherry-red spot with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). Fundoscopy may also show Hollenhorst plaque. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Optic neuritis (ON) presents as diminished visual acuity or decreased color perception (desaturation) in the central field of vision. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is seen in optic neuritis. These symptoms can be mild or may progress to severe visual loss. Periorbital pain (aggravated by eye movement) often precedes or accompanies the visual loss.

The following image shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.



Other specific Pupillary signs:

Argyll Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus. When light is shone on the pupils, they do not react. However, they contract on convergence. 

The tonic pupil of Adie is a dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. The affected pupil is dilated. When light is shone on the pupil, constriction is present but is of low magnitude. It has sluggish reaction to convergenece.

An absolute afferent pupillary defect (amaurotic pupil) is caused by a complete optic nerve lesion where the involved eye is completely blind. When light is shone on the affected eye, neither pupil constricts. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict.

questions.text: 159. Behcet's disease is characterized by all of the following clinical features except:
questions.solution:
Myocarditis is not seen in Behcet’s disease.

Behcet’s syndrome is characterized by:

* Erythema nodosum

* Athralgia/arthritis

* Oral and genital ulcers

Diagnostic criteria: Recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following is required:

* Recurrent genital ulcerations 

* Eye lesions- anterior and posterior uveitis

* Skin lesions- erythema nodosum, papulopustular nodules, and pseudofolliculitis.

* Positive Pathergy test- inflammatory skin reaction occurring due to scratching or injection of normal saline in patients with Behcet's syndrome

questions.text: 160. Which of the following statements does not apply to cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in a cross-examination according to Sec. 143 IEA. However, they are not allowed during the direct examination conducted by the summoning counsel.

In the event that Judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination. 

Leading questions (Sec. 141 IEA) are defined as questions that suggest an answer that is favorable for the case of the summoning counsel or in alignment with their claim. 

Other options:

Options 1, 3, 4 - In cross-examination, the witness is examined by the defense lawyer or adverse party with an objective to elicit favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and also, to discredit the witness. 

While leading questions are allowed in cross-examination, the Judge can disallow questions that are indecent (Sec. 151 IEA) or questions asked with an intention to insult or offend the witness in any form (Sec. 152 IEA).

There is no time limit to the duration of cross-examination. 

 

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective
  • Examination-in-Chief/ Direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed.
  • Cross-examination by the defense lawyer
 To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness. Leading questions are allowed.
  • Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness
 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

questions.text: 161. A surgeon has been performing a difficult neck dissection for the past 3 hours. During the procedure, he has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following triangles of the neck, is he probably dissecting?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

* Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery

* Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery

* Internal jugular vein

* Vagus nerve

* Hypoglossal nerve

* Spinal part of the accessory

* Sympathetic chain

* Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: 162. Bone marrow suppression is least severe with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow suppression is least severe with vincristine.

Vinblastine, vinorelbine, and methotrexate cause prominent bone marrow depression.

Bone marrow–sparing cytotoxic drugs:

* Vincristine

* Bleomycin

* L-asparaginase

questions.text: 163. A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and also unilateral nasal obstruction, and denasal speech. Contrast contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Antral sign or Holman Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumour grows into the:

* Nasal cavity

* Nasopharynx

* Pterygopalatine fossa

* Pterygomaxillary fossa

* Infratemporal fossa

OTHER OPTIONS:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumour mass in glomus tumour, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. 

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - Antral sign or Holman Miller sign.

questions.text:
164. A 28-year-old primigravida in her third trimester presented with a history of sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding. On evaluation, a diagnosis of placenta previa was made. A decision was taken to manage her condition using the McAfee and Johnson regimen. Which of the following criteria should be met for the same?

1) Assured fetal well being

2) Duration of pregnancy > 37 weeks

3) No active vaginal bleeding 

4) Maternal hemoglobin > 10g%
questions.solution:
The patient has been diagnosed with placenta previa. The criteria which have to be met for the expectant management regimen proposed by McAfee and Johnson include assured fetal well-being, no active vaginal bleeding, and maternal hemoglobin > 10 g%. 

A patient with diagnosed placenta previa and duration of pregnancy >37 weeks cannot be managed expectantly. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. Termination of expectant management is done at 37 weeks when the fetus is sufficiently mature to survive.

McAfee and Johnson expectant management regimen:

Prerequisites:

* Availability of blood for transfusion 

* Facilities for cesarean sections are available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

* Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 

* Duration of pregnancy < 37 weeks 

* No active vaginal bleeding 

* The fetus was normal on ultrasound and reactive on cardiotocography

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

* Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 

* Bed rest or pelvic rest

* Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV

* Fetal surveillance with USG  

* Tocolytics if contractions are present

* Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women

questions.text: 165. A male patient presented with discoloration of his nails over the past 6 months. The findings of the physical examination are shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for treating the pathology depicted in this image?

choices.text: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Formation of pores in cell membrane
Inhibition of squalene epoxidase involved in ergosterol synthesis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing the yellowish discoloration of his nails, is suggestive of onychomycosis. Terbinafine is used for the treatment of this condition. The mechanism of action of terbinafine is the inhibition of squalene epoxidase, which is involved in ergosterol synthesis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early-step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases of onychomycosis.

Treatment of onychomycosis:

First-line drug Duration
Oral terbinafine - 250 mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral itraconazole- 400 mg/day for 1 week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months


It is observed that terbinafine, given as one 250 mg tablet daily for adults is somewhat more effective than itraconazole for nail onychomycosis. Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is used as a second-line drug.

Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non-linear superficial onychomycosis.

Pearl PM2339: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: 166. A patient's breast lump biopsy findings reveal that she has stage IV breast cancer with extensive metastases. You follow a six-step protocol to convey this result to your patient. Which of the following is the first step involved in this protocol?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

* S - Setting up the interview

* P - Assessing the patient’s perception

* I - Obtaining the patient’s invitation

* K - Giving knowledge and information to the patient

* E - Addressing the patient’s emotions with empathic responses

* S - Strategy, and summary

Key components of the SPIKES strategy:

*

* Demonstrating empathy

* Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings

* Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news

* Providing information about possible interventions

Greeting is used as a first step in the GATHER approach which is a method of communication used for counseling, wherein a person is helped to make decisions about health. e.g contraceptive counselling

* G- Greet

* A- Ask

* T- Tell options or give answers

* H- Help in making choices

* E- Explain everything about the decision

* R- Return for follow-up

questions.text: 167. A 35-year-old female patient diagnosed with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is on treatment with procainamide. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the drug?

choices.text: Procainamide is used in the management of  ventricular tachycardia.
N-acetyl procainamide lacks the sodium channel–blocking property.
Long-term usage can cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is that it has α-adrenergic-blocking activity. It is not an alpha-blocker.

Procainamide belongs to the class IA of antiarrhythmics. It has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels.

It is metabolized in the liver to N­-acetyl­ procainamide (NAPA). NAPA has no Na+ channel-blocking property but can block the potassium channels and prolongs repolarization. Procainamide is used in the acute treatment of  Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with atrial fibrillation. It can be used in the acute and chronic treatment of atrial fibrillation (AF), ventricular fibrillation (VF), and tachycardia (VT).

Long-term therapy of procainamide can cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus. It resolves on the cessation of therapy or on treatment with only the metabolite N-acetyl procainamide. Torsades de pointes occurring in procainamide toxicity.
