questions.text: 168. Which of the following marked layers gives rise to the only efferent of the cerebellar cortex?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the marked structure B i.e. the Purkinje cell layer gives rise to the only efferent of the cerebellar cortex. The axons of Purkinje cells are inhibitory to the cerebellar nuclei.

The structures marked in the given image are:

* A - Molecular layer

* B - Purkinje cell layer

* C - Granular layer

* D - White matter

The cerebellum is covered by pia mater which is seen as thin connective tissue, with blood vessels lying under it. The cerebellum consists of outer grey matter (cerebellar cortex) and inner white matter.



Pearl PM2250: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

* Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.

* Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.

* Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.



Neurotransmitters released:

* Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA

* Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: 169. A 60-year-old male patient comes for a follow-up after a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) one week back. He complains of not being able to name anything. On examination, he understands and talks normally, but he is unable to repeat the words told to him. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure affected in this patient is the arcuate fasciculus.

The above clinical features are suggestive of conduction aphasia as his comprehension of spoken language and speech fluency is intact with repetition being impaired. Naming is impaired here. The site of lesion usually affected in conduction aphasia is the arcuate fasciculus.

Arcuate fasciculus is short association fibres that connect the temporal cortex and inferior parietal cortex to the frontal lobe. One of its important connections is that between the Broca's area and Wernicke's area.

Association fibres: They connect various cortical areas within the same hemisphere. They are classified as:

* Short association fibres: they connect adjacent gyri. Example: Arcuate fasciculus

* Long association fibres: they connect gyri from one lobe to another lobe. Example:

* Superior longitudinal fasciculus

* Inferior longitudinal fasciculus

* Fronto-occipital fasciculus

* Cingulum

* Uncinate fasciculus

* Fornix 

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is present in the inferior frontal lobe of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, comprehension of language is intact, speech fluency, repetition and naming are impaired.

Option C- Wernicke's area (Brodmann's area 22) corresponds to the supramarginal gyrus within the inferior parietal lobule of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Wernicke's aphasia or sensory aphasia. In Wernicke's aphasia, comprehension of language, repetition and naming are impaired. Speech fluency is increased associated with new words (neologism) resulting in jargon aphasia.

Option D- Middle longitudinal fasciculus is an association fibre in the superior temporal gyrus connecting angular gyrus (area 39) with the superior temporal gyrus (area 22). It plays a role in linguistic processing with information dealing with the spatial organization, memory, and motivational valence.

Pearl PM2240: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

* Corpus callosum

* Anterior and posterior commissure

* Habenular commissure

* Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

* Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus

* Long association fibers:

* Uncinate fasciculus

* Cingulum

* Superior longitudinal fasciculus

* Inferior longitudinal fasciculus

* Fronto-occipital fasciculus

* Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)



Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

* Internal capsule

* Corona radiata

questions.text: 170. A 25-year-old obese woman comes to the clinic with complaints of multiple painful lesions associated with a foul-smelling discharge in the axilla. Examination findings are as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple lesions with foul-smelling discharge in the intertriginous area (axilla) in an obese female is strongly suggestive of hidradenitis suppurativa.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is also called acne inversa and is seen more commonly seen after puberty. It is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

* Typical lesions - The lesions can manifest as deep‐seated painful nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudo comedones.

* Typical locations - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks, and infra‐ and intermammary folds.

* Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

Treatment includes: 

* General measures - lifestyle modifications such as cessation of smoking, weight loss, and general cleanliness are advised. 

* Antibiotics - Topical clindamycin lotion 0.1% can be used to manage milder lesions. Systemic antibiotics like tetracycline and a combination of clindamycin and rifampicin can be used in such conditions.

* Intralesional corticosteroids such a triaminolone can be used.

* Acitretin

* Anti-TNF alpha therapy

* Surgery - Many lesion‐directed therapies have been identified as beneficial in the therapy of HS. Incision and drainage are done in a presence of a fluctuant abscess. Deroofing can also be done which is a tissue-saving procedure in which the roof of an abscess or sinus tract is surgically removed using either electrosurgery (using a loop) or conventional surgery. Ablative lasers and electrosurgery are also useful in removing all the involved tissues. 

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris is one of the most common skin diseases, highly prevalent in adolescents. The lesions can manifest as open and closed comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules with variable degrees of inflammation and depth. The most usually affected areas are the face, back, and/or chest. These would not be found in the axillary region.



Option B: Necrobiosis lipoidica can happen at any age, it typically is seen in young adults and those in their early middle years. It is associated with diabetes. The lesion starts as a hard, dull red papule or plaque on the pretibial skin and enlarges radially to become a yellowish atrophic plaque with an erythematous edge. Telangiectatic vessels may be seen, and the surface is frequently glazed in appearance.



Option C: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare non‐infectious neutrophilic dermatosis. It is commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The major criteria to diagnosis classical PG are a rapid progression of a painful, necrolytic cutaneous ulcer with an irregular, violaceous, and undermined border; and the elimination of any other causes of cutaneous ulceration. These lesions are usually not found in the axilla.

questions.text: 171. An autopsy of a police officer revealed a bullet in the parapharyngeal space. There is a small healed entry wound on the neck. The bullet is surrounded by fibrous tissue and there is no fresh bleeding around it. What is this bullet called?
questions.solution:
This bullet is called a souvenir bullet.

A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on x-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the skull.

Other options - 

Option A - Dumdum bullets are bullets that fragment extensively when they hit an object.

Option B - Tracer bullets leave a visible trace while in flight which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. A small portion in the rear of the bullet is devoid of the core. This space is filled with a flammable chemical compound that is red in color. Flash from the propellant ignites this mixture that causes the bullet to shed red sparks during flight.

The image shows tracer bullets:



Option D - Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet) is when two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It occurs when the first bullet has been struck in the barrel, fails to leave, and gets ejected with subsequently fired bullet.

Pearl PM1808: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .



2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.



3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 



4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.



5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.



6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  



7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.



8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.



9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: 172. A patient is undergoing surgical resection of a large swelling as shown below. The CT scan showed a lesion greater than 10 cm with thick septa and foci of nodular enhancement. Biopsy revealed mature adipose tissue infiltrating the adjacent structures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with a CT scan showing a large lesion, thick septa, foci of nodular enhancement, and a biopsy revealing mature adipose tissue infiltrating the adjacent structures has the most likely diagnosis as liposarcoma.

It is the most common retroperitoneal sarcoma seen in the 5-6th decade. They present at late stages with non-specific symptoms. CT can be useful in diagnosis. 

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Retroperitoneal teratoma is a germ cell tumor characterized by fat components, cystic areas, and calcifications in a CT. Surgical resection is the main treatment of choice.

Option B: Leiomyosarcoma is the second most common retroperitoneal tumor seen in 50-60 years of age. It is characterized by a bulk mass with necrosis, with or without hemorrhage.

Option D: Myxofibrosarcoma is seen in individuals with a mean age of 65 years. They have non-specific findings in imaging.

questions.text: 173. During an experiment, it was found that a skeletal muscle's latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period were 15 ms, 30 ms, and 60 ms, respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency.
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 33 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanizing frequency = 1/30 per millisecond = 1/0.03 per second = 1000/30 per second = 33 per second.

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types, complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fiber before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text: 174. While conducting a health camp, you host an awareness campaign on healthy dietary practices. Which of the following substances would you say has the highest respiratory quotient immediately after consumption?
questions.solution:
The food item with the highest respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after consumption is a mixed diet. 

This is because, immediately after a mixed meal (containing carbohydrates, protein, and fat), carbohydrates is the most commonly metabolized component, so the RQ reaches 1. But, a few hours after, the body would have used up the readily available carbohydrates, and the RQ reaches 0.70, due to fat metabolism.

The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide produced/oxygen consumed. The respiratory quotient for various substances:

Substance RQ
Carbohydrate 1.00 
Protein (option D) 0.81 
Fat (option B) 0.71  
Alcohol (option C) 0.66 


In diabetes, the rate of utilization of carbohydrates reduces in relation to fats, hence RQ falls (approximately 0.7). The RQ is lowest when ketosis is very active.

Note: For all metabolic fuels, the energy produced is the same (20 kJ/L of oxygen).

questions.text: 175. A 5-year-old male child presents with high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals swelling of the knee joint and tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. All of the following factors contribute to metaphyseal involvement in this infection, except _____.
questions.solution:
The complaints of fever, pain, and swelling of the knee following an episode of sore throat along with raised ESR, CRP, and leucocytosis in a child point to a diagnosis of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. A faint extracortical line on X-ray due to periosteal new bone formation is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis. Slow growth is not a reason for metaphyseal involvement in this infection.

Osteomyelitis in children usually starts in the vascular metaphysis of a long bone and the following local factors are important causes that contribute to this:

* The hairpin bend of the metaphyseal vessels slows down the circulation and allows organisms to escape out of the vessel. (Option A)

* Metaphyseal hemorrhage occur due to microscopic trauma and the clot so formed acts as an excellent culture media for the bacteria to grow. (Option B)

* Defective phagocytosis is present. WBCs remove the debris of the decalcification occurring in the growth process and their function of eliminating the offending organism is slightly impaired. (Option C)

* The rapid growth of the metaphyseal cells makes them susceptible to the action of bacterial toxins as they are immature. (Option D)

* Vasospasm arrests further bleeding from the traumatized vessels but cause anoxia and failure of antibiotics and other defense cells from reaching the area.

Pearl PM0011: Types of Bone sequestra seen in chronic osteomyelitis

Types of Bone sequestra seen in chronic osteomyelitis:

Type Disease
Tubular Pyogenic

Black/coke Actinomycosis
Coralliform Perthe's disease

questions.text: 176. You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the area marked 'x' in the image given below, you are likely to find all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.



The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises  1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

* Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.

* Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.

* Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Pearl PM0706: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres



* Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.

* Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 

* Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.

* The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.

* Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.

* The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.

* Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.

* In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.

* In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.

* The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: 177. A 30-year-old woman comes with complaints of drooping eyelids and double vision in both eyes, The symptoms worsen with repetitive eye movements and resolve after rest. Chest radiography revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is not a feature of her condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of intermittent complaints of ptosis and weakness of extraocular muscles (causing diplopia), which worsen after repetitive eye movements, is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Chest radiography showing an anterior mediastinal mass (most likely a thymoma) supports this diagnosis. Deep tendon reflexes are normal in myasthenia gravis, not absent.

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest or chest radiography.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. Weakness of the muscles of the face (option C), palate and tongue may lead to difficulty in swallowing (option D). When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs (option A) are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

* Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay

* Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response

* Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG

* Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium

* Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

* Presence of thymoma

* Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient.

Pearl PM1844: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: 178. A 60-year-old woman was found to have complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?

choices.text: Progesterone therapy and endometrial biopsy every 6 months
Progesterone therapy only for a duration of  2 years

questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the above case.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

* Simple without atypia: there is an increase in number of glands but the architecture is not compromised. 

* Simple with atypia: simple hyperplasia with features of nuclear atypia (variation in nuclear shape, size, and prominent nucleoli)

* Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded and irregular

* Complex with atypia: complex hyperplasia with atypical nuclear features. 

However, there is generally no clear histological distinction between the above mentioned classification, so endometrial hyperplasia is classified into hyperplasia without atypia and atypical hyperplasia/endometrioid intraepithelial neoplasia. 

Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%


Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Hyperplasia without atypia:

Intrauterine or continuous oral progesterone. Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system is preferred due to its lower side effect profile, higher rate of disease resolution. Oral progesterone can be given in the form of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10-20 mg/day. 

Endometrial surveillance in the form of biopsy should be performed at 6-month intervals. At least 2 consecutive negative biopsies should be obtained. Those at high risk (body mass index of more than 35, treated with oral progesterone) should be advised annual follow-up. 

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is suggested in those with atypical hyperplasia due to the risk of progression to malignancy. 

Premenopausal women who want to preserve their fertility should be counseled regarding the risk of progression to cancer. Once fertility is no longer required, then hysterectomy should be offered. 

Those who refuse hysterectomy should have routine endometrial biopsies every 3 months until 2 consecutive negative biopsies are obtained.

questions.text: 179. A 50-year-old male patient with a recent history of myocardial infarction was started on aspirin. Which of the following statements is true about the drug used?

choices.text: Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets
Alkalinization of urine decreases its rate of excretion
Antiplatelet action is seen at higher doses

questions.solution:
Low-dose aspirin acetylates the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme of platelets which is responsible for its antiplatelet action.

Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug that acts by irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibition. Anti-inflammatory action is exerted at high doses (325-650 mg every 4 to 6 hours) and anti-platelet action is exerted at low doses of 40–80 mg/day.

Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin. Aspirin clearance does depend on its plasma concentration since at lower plasma concentrations it has first-order kinetics, where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration, but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is independent of its plasma concentration.

Aspirin can be used as an analgesic, antipyretic and anti-inflammatory drug in rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, rheumatic fever, in the prevention of pre-eclampsia, and in post-myocardial infarction and post-stroke patients.

The most important adverse effect of aspirin is gastric mucosal damage and peptic ulceration. In children with viral illnesses, the drug may cause Reye's syndrome, a rare form of hepatic encephalopathy. It is a hepatotoxic drug and toxicity occurs when the dose exceeds 15g/day in adults. In patients with aspirin resistance, there is a failure of aspirin to produce its normal platelet inhibitory functions. Aspirin intolerance is a part of Samter's triad (nasal polyposis, intrinsic asthma, and aspirin intolerance).

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: 180. A 28-year-old woman was detected with a positive antibody titer against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. All of the following steps are catalyzed by this enzyme for the synthesis of thyroid hormones except?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

* Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter.

* Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloid.

* Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 

* Oxidation: TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2

* Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)

* Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)

* Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months

* Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 

* Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text: 181. Which of the following statements is true about G banding?

choices.text: Silver salts are used for staining
Staining pattern is specific for each chromosome

questions.solution:
The true statement about G banding is that the staining pattern is specific for each chromosome. 

G banding is a technique for the identification of chromosomes and their abnormalities. In this technique, chromosomes are stained using Giemsa stain. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype.

G banding is based on differential staining of the GC-rich and AT-rich areas of the chromosome. Heterochromatin regions which are AT-rich DNA and relatively gene-poor stain more darkly. Whereas, euchromatin regions that are GC-rich (and more transcriptionally active) incorporate less Giemsa stain and appear as light bands in G-banding. 

The image below shows the G banding of chromosomes.



Various techniques are used in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Staining with various compounds produces various results and helps us to understand the chromosomes better.

Common techniques used are:

* Q banding - fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard

* G banding - Giemsa staining after partial denaturation of chromatin

* R banding - reverse Giemsa staining. In this, the light and dark areas are reversed

* C banding - staining of heterochromatin with silver salts

* T banding - staining the telomeres of chromosomes

C banding: Heterochromatin includes non-coding regions of DNA, such as centromeric regions. The staining of these constitutive heterochromatins is done by C-banding using silver salt staining. A dicentric chromosome having two centromeres can hence be identified by C banding.

The given image shows NOR banding:

questions.text: 182. According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex preserves the vaginal length and maintains the horizontal axis, anchors the vagina to the levator plate, and positions the cervix just above the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.



Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.

questions.text: 183. A 37-year-old man, with no known medical illness, came for a routine medical check-up. His chest radiograph is presented to you. Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

* Trachea

* Right atrial border

* Left ventricular border

* Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text: 184. Which of the following is not a neutralization test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann test is an example of a complement fixation test, not a neutralization test.

Wassermann test is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).



Examples of neutralization tests include

* Virus neutralization tests: Neutralization of viruses by antibodies.

* Plaque inhibition test for neutralization of bacteriophages

* Toxin neutralization tests: Bacterial exotoxins neutralization by antibodies

* Nagler reaction: done for the detection of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens

* Schick test: Neutralization of diphtheria toxin by circulating antitoxin

* Anti-streptolysin O test: Neutralization of streptococcal O hemolysin produced by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Note: Anti-streptolysin O test is both an agglutination and a neutralization test.

questions.text: 185. A 32-year-old man presents with complaints of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower for the past few months. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL and his erythropoietin levels are low. Which of the following cannot be used in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera and nitrosourea is not used in the treatment of polycythemia vera. 

Alkylating agents like nitrosourea are leukemogenic in polycythemia vera and its contraindicated. 

Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation on Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. 

Polycythemia shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. 

Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis.

Treatment: Phlebotomy serves initially to reduce the hyperviscosity by reducing the red cell mass. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine.

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text:
186. Abuse of which of the following drugs will lead to the finding as shown in the image below?

* Heroin

* Cocaine

* Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)

* Mescaline

* Cannabis
questions.solution:
The given image shows circular depressed skin popping scars in this patient. Among the given options, opioids like heroin and cocaine abuse ( 1 and 2) can lead to this.

Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Illicit drugs like heroin, cocaine, and barbiturates are injected by this method. It has slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration when compared to intravenous drug use. Skin popping scars point to possible drug use.

Opioids can be taken orally, snorted, or injected intravenously. It results in a euphoric high, especially with the intravenous route. The associated features are heaviness of the extremities, dry mouth, itchy face, and facial flushing. It can result in constipation, pupillary constriction, and changes in blood pressure. The clinical triad of coma, pinpoint pupils, and respiratory depression points are suggestive of opioid overdose. Respiratory depression can even lead to death.

Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), mescaline (hallucinogen), and cannabis are not usually taken through injections, but commonly by oral route or through smoking.

Head-to-toe examination in cases of substance abuse becomes important to look for such skin findings. Long-term use of cocaine can result in cocaine nose, with perforation of the nasal septum, as seen in the image below.

questions.text: 187. A 7-year-old boy is brought with complaints of headache, vomiting and neck stiffness for a few days. He had undergone a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement for hydrocephalus a few months back. Which of the following is the most common cause for shunt malfunction?
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the shunt is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following -

* Shunt obstruction - most common cause for shunt malfunction

* Shunt infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, most commonly from Staphylococcus epidermidis. 

* Intracerebral or intraventricular haemorrhage

* Tip migration or malposition

* Shunt overdrainage (slit ventricle syndrome) - usually occurs after many years

* Shunt nephritis

* Shunt disconnection or breakage or kinking

* Inguinal hernia

* Seizures

Shunt obstruction -

* It is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.

* The most common site is the ventricular catheter.

* Obstruction occurs due to clogging of the shunt by blood, proteinaceous material, choroid plexus, glial adhesions or secondary to infection.

* The patient comes with features of raised intracranial pressure like headache, vomiting and eye examination showing papilloedema. 

* Diagnosis is done by CT Brain imaging which shows ventriculomegaly. On performing a lumbar puncture, the CSF flow is found to be slow despite the raised CSF pressure.

* Treatment is by revision of the shunt.

 

The image below shows the location of the shunt in the brain



The image below shows a CT scan of the brain with some proteinaceous material deposited in the ventricles and shunt insitu.

questions.text: 188. Which of the following IPC/BNS sections deals with causing feticide in a pregnant woman with an intent to prevent a developed child from being born alive?
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 91 (IPC 315) deals with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth. The pre-requisite associated with this IPC is that the fetus must be in an advanced stage of development that would make it sufficiently capable of leading an extra-uterine existence. The offender is liable to imprisonment for up to 10 years, with a fine, or both.

Other options:

Option 1 - BNS Sec 89 (IPC 313) deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with child (and/or quick with child) without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment. 

Option 3 - BNS Sec 88 (IPC 312) deals with the causation of criminal abortion (no therapeutic indication to do so) with the consent of the pregnant woman. Both the pregnant woman and the abortionist are liable to punishment. 

Option 4 - BNS Sec 90 (IPC 314) deals with the death of a pregnant woman from an act intended to cause miscarriage. In such a case, the abortionist/offender is liable to punishment including imprisonment of at least 10 years and a fine. If the act of miscarriage was undertaken after conducting a prenatal sex determination (female fetus confirmation), the offender is liable to life imprisonment and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees.

questions.text: 190. An asthmatic patient comes with fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea and is diagnosed with HIV. He has been using oral ketoconazole for tinea infection. Which of the following drugs should not be concomitantly used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is taking ketoconazole should not receive saquinavir—a protease inhibitor.

The antifungal agent ketoconazole is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and other CYPs, and coadministration of ketoconazole with the anti-HIV viral protease inhibitors reduces the clearance of the protease inhibitor and increases its plasma concentration and the risk of toxicity.

* Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI) like abacavir and zidovudine do not interact much with CYP enzymes. (Option A and B)

* The only nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor tenofovir does not interact much with CYP enzymes. (Option D)

* Nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) like efavirenz and nevirapine are moderately potent inducers of hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes, including CYP3A4.

* Protease inhibitors inhibit CYP3A4 at clinically achieved concentrations, with ritonavir by far the most potent.

questions.text: 191. Which of the following is not an initiative under the Employees' state insurance (ESI) scheme?
questions.solution:
Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana is not an initiative under the Employees state insurance (ESI) scheme. It is a flagship social welfare program intended to provide housing for all in urban areas all over the India.

Abhiyan Indradhanush in relation to the ESI scheme refers to the change of bedsheets on a daily basis from Sunday to Saturday based on the VIBGYOR pattern for the color of the bedsheet.

Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana is an ESI scheme of unemployment allowance. As per this scheme, an insured person who becomes unemployed after being insured for three or more years, due to the closure of a factory/establishment, retrenchment, or permanent invalidity is entitled to:

* Unemployment allowance equal to 50% of wage for a maximum period of up to 2 years.

* Medical care for self and family from ESI hospitals/dispensaries during the period of unemployment allowance.

* Vocational training provided for upgrading skills - expenditure on fee/traveling allowance borne by ESIC.

Extended sickness benefit is offered to insured people of the ESI scheme, who are suffering from certain chronic diseases, for a maximum period of 2 years, in addition to the 91 days of leave they are entitled to under the sickness benefit. During this period, they are paid about 80% of the average daily wages. The insured person should have been working for a continuous period of 2 years. There are 34 listed diseases for which the extended sickness benefit can be availed.

* Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.

* Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.

* Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

* Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

* Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.

* Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

* Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 

* The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.

* Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.

* Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

* Disablement Benefits–

* Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.

* Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.

* Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.

* Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

* Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.

* Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.

* Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

* Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.

* Healthy-work force.

questions.text: 192. You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area. You remove a Guinea worm from a patient by rolling it over a stick as shown below. The intermediate host of this parasite is also implicated in which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm (Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick. It is transmitted by the cyclops which also serves as the intermediate host for Diphyllobothrium latum/fish tapeworm.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinensis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

Life cycle of Dracunculus medinensis/Gunea worm :



Treatment:

* No drug cures the infection 

* Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.

* A simple surgical procedure can be done to remove the worm.

* Topical antibiotics may be used to limit bacterial superinfection

Life cycle of fish tapeworm :



Diphyllobothrium latum requires 3 hosts – definitive host: man; first intermediate host: cyclops; and second intermediate host: cyclops and fish. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

They are known to cause deficiency of vitamin B12 (Bothriocephalus anemia). The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency. In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Treatment for  Diphyllobothrum latum infection is Praziquantel.

Other options :

Option A: Hymenolepis nana is the only cestode that completes its life cycle in a single host. There is no intermediate host.

Option C: Multiceps multiceps/Taenia Multiceps is a cestode that has dogs as its primary host and sheep and rodents serve as the intermediate hosts.

Option D: Schistosoma haematobium / blood fluke completes its life cycle with freshwater snails are intermediate hosts.

questions.text: 193. Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern occurs in all of the following conditions, except ________.
questions.solution:
Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern does not occur in acromegaly.

Fingerprints are impressions of patterns formed by the papillary or epidermal ridges of the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but is unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of the individual.

However, permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electrical injury, and subsequent radiation exposure.

In acromegaly, there is a change in the distance between the ridges but no permanent impairment in the fingerprint pattern. A similar change is observed in infantile paralysis and rickets. Ridge alteration can also occur in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin. Additionally, there is moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease.

questions.text: 194. Which of the following is false about Schroeders' ring?

choices.text: Common cause is injudicious administration of oxytocics
The ring can be felt per abdomen
It is usually formed around the neck of the fetus

questions.solution:
The ring is not felt per abdomen.

Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin results in the formation of a constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring.

It is usually situated at the junction of the upper and lower segment of the uterus around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation. The ring is not felt per abdomen. The uterus never ruptures.

Common causes are:

* Injudicious use of oxytocics

* Premature rupture of membranes

* A premature attempt at instrumental delivery

Management

Delivery is usually done by cesarean section. The ring usually passes off by deepening the plane of anesthesia otherwise the ring may have to be cut vertically to deliver the baby.

questions.text: 195. The occurrence of dengue infection in Bangladesh has been documented as illustrated below. This epidemiological pattern represents which of the following types of trends?
questions.solution:
The increase in incidence of dengue during months September through November each year during this 2 year time frame is described as a seasonal trend.

Seasonal trends reflect seasonal changes in disease occurrence following changes in environmental conditions that enhance the ability of the agent to replicate or be transmitted. For example, measles (usually occurs in early spring), varicella, etc. Non-infectious conditions like hay fever and snake bites may also show seasonal variations.

Other options:

Option A: The secular trend describes the occurrence of disease over a prolonged period, usually years. Even though it may have short-term fluctuations, there is a tendency of the disease occurrence to change consistently in a particular direction or a definite movement in one direction.

Examples of the secular trend include coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and diabetes, which have shown a consistent upward trend in incidence as well as prevalence, in developed countries. Similarly, there has been a consistent decline in the diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio.

Option B: Cyclic trend is shown by some diseases that occur in cycles spread over short periods of time which may be, days, weeks, months, or years.  Examples include the influenza pandemic, which is known to occur at intervals of every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations.

Option C: Propagative epidemics are most likely infectious in origin. They gradually rise and tapers over a long period of time. Examples include polio, hepatitis A.

questions.text: 196. A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of dull aching pain in the lower abdomen for the past 8 months. There is no clinical evidence of any pelvic pathology. She says the pain decreases on lying down and increases on walking, bending, and standing. You diagnose her with having chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Which of the following is false regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Conscious pain mapping is not useful in diagnosis

questions.solution:
Conscious pain mapping is a useful investigation in the diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Conscious pain mapping is a laparoscopic technique used to identify and understand the source of pelvic pain by directly observing and manipulating the pelvic organs under conscious sedation or local anesthesia.

Chronic pelvic pain (CPP) refers to acyclical pelvic pain of more than 6 months duration. Chronic pelvic pain syndrome is a condition characterized by CPP not associated with any clinical evidence of pelvic pathology. It possibly occurs because of dilated pelvic veins. And, hence, shifting the location of pain with body movement is characteristic of this syndrome.

It is associated with congestive dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital ache, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Doppler ultrasound and venography help in the diagnosis. Conscious pain mapping at laparoscopy under local anesthesia is useful in deciding the cause and location of chronic pain. This improves diagnostic accuracy.

Treatment comprises progestogen therapy. Progestogens, by their anti-estrogenic effect, constrict the veins, reduce blood flow, and suppress ovulation.

questions.text: 197. A 62-year-old woman is found to have a Hb of 7.2 g/dL and high ferritin levels. She has been undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer since the last year. What change would you expect in the serum hepcidin levels of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this condition is hepcidin, a positive acute-phase reactant (APR) that increases in chronic inflammatory states.

It binds with ferroportin, which reduces the iron intake in the gut and reduces iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. This is reflected by a low serum iron level, increased red cell protoporphyrin level, a hyperproliferative marrow, and normal or increased serum ferritin level. Hepcidin is a negative regulator of iron balance.

Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies.

questions.text: 198. An epidemiologist is studying changes in the population of a country with time. This process is called the demographic cycle. Which of the following options best defines the correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: High expanding→ Early stationary → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining
High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

The demographic cycle is comprised of five stages and is as described below:

Stage 1: High stationary population - There is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

Stage 2: Early expanding population - There is a decline in the death rate that begins but the birth rate stays constant. Ex: Many countries in South Asia, and Africa are in this phase. 

Stage 3: Late expanding population - There is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase.

Stage 4: Low stationary population - There is a low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It can also result in zero population growth like in Austria (1980-85). Other examples: the UK, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium recorded a growth rate of 0.1 in 1980-85. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

Stage 5: Contracting population - The birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Ex: East European countries like Germany, and Hungary.

India is currently in the "late expanding" stage which is the third stage in the demographic cycle where declining death rates and declining birth rates are seen.

Another important concept of the demographic cycle is the demographic gap which is the difference between birth rate and death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both birth rate and death rate falls causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Pearl PM1694: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

* Stage 1 - High stationary 

* High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary

* Narrow demographic gap

* Stage 2 - Early expanding 

* The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged

* The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum

* Stage 3 - Late expanding

* Death rate declines further and birth rate falls

* India is in this stage, currently

* The demographic gap starts declining

* Stage 4 - Low stationary 

* Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary

* Narrow demographic gap

* Stage 5 - Declining 

* The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate

* The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: 199. Identify the components of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.
questions.solution:
The components of the CRISPR-9 gene-editing tool are guide RNA and Cas9 nuclease.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. It uses guide RNA transcribed from CRISPR DNA (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Palindromic Repeats of DNA) and a Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) nuclease.

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted.

This technique can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of the CRISPR/ Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: 200. Which of the following RNA is involved in mRNA splicing?
questions.solution:
snRNA or small nuclear RNA plays a role in mRNA splicing. They take part in the formation of spliceosomes.

Other options:

Option A: miRNA (micro RNA) is derived from large primary transcripts through specific nucleolytic processing. It modulates gene expression by altering mRNA function. They bind to matching pieces of mRNA, turn it into a double strand and arrest the translation. 

Option B:  rRNAs are involved in protein synthesis. They facilitate the interaction of mRNA, tRNA, and amino acids to interact with each other for the translation process. 

Option C: siRNA or interfering RNA is mainly involved in RNA interference. They degrade the mRNA through specific cytoplasmic organelles called P bodies.
